item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-220] Mosaic creation java process can exit with a non-zero status code
item.description:
With my Windows 7 64 bits, JRE 1.6.0_18-b07, both with cygwin and ant, I've observed that:

1) Mosaic creation process exits with non-zero return code, below. This causes our ant build process that uses the mosaic tool to halt.
Java returned: -1073741819

2) It occurs on my cygwin's raw java invocation too, not just within ant. Only happens on Windows, it works fine on Mac. The mosaic is created successfully, just the exit code is non-zero.

3) I've seen that the exit code becomes 0 if I add "-show_mosaic" option to the tool invocation, or if I comment out the System.exit(0) line at the end of Main.main(String[] args).

While I suspect that this is a JDK problem, I'm going to remove this one line from Main method because it should be harmless, and that there's one posting on the hdcookbook forum reporting the same issue.

$ svn diff
Index: jdktools/binaryconverter/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/binaryconverter/Main.java
===================================================================
— jdktools/binaryconverter/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/binaryconverter/Main.java (revision 656)
+++ jdktools/binaryconverter/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/binaryconverter/Main.java (working copy)
@@ -244,7 +246,8 @@
e.printStackTrace();
System.exit(1);
}

  • System.exit(0);
    + //System.exit(0); /// FIXME: This causes the negative value exit problem
    }

private static int argToInt(String s) {

Object.

So I suggest revise the element as following.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-216] More efficient commands and java_command parameters
item.description:
java_command has always been a little incomplete, because it has no way of being parameterized. A bit of history
here: java_command was a relatively late addition to GRIN. By the time it came along, the four commands that take
parameters in com.hdcookbook.grin.commands already existed. Here, a parameter is a feature, segment or RC
handler reference that the command uses to do its work; activate_segement needs a segment reference.

java_command lets you write arbitrary code for a command. It's very powerful and general, and it was implemented
the way it was to avoid what one could call the "command pattern trap." Because Java doesn't pre-link classes, every
time you add a runtime class to an xlet you pay a classload penalty. This has been observed to be a pretty big
penalty on modest players: 30 ms/class. One of the architectural principles of GRIN is to minimize startup time,
because that's one of the big pain points of BD-J. java_command helps do that; if java_command replaces 30
command subclasses with one subclass and a switch statement, that's a startup time gain of about a second. One
second times 10 million disc inserts is roughly four months of time saved! Also, it's really annoying to wait for a disc
to start up.

By adding parameters to java_command, more needless subclassing can be avoided, and the four commands in
com.hdcookbook.grin.commands could even be eliminated, and folded into GrinXHelper. The problem is that
parameters are typed, and we don't want to add a ton of data members to GrinXHelper. That's easy to handle,
though, by having an Object[] data member called "parameters," and using downcasting. Downcasting is quite fast
in Java.

State variables could be introduced with parameters that are arrays (example below).

If this addition were added, GRIN extensions could implement their own syntax-friendly extension commands on
top of the java_command compiler/runtime infrastructure, so enhancing java_command in this way could make
extension commands in general more efficient, and not just java_command.

Here's an idea for a new java_command syntax:

java_command ::= "java_command" java_parameters "[[" java_source "]]"

java_parameters ::= # nothing

"(" java_parameter ( "," java_parameter )* ")"

java_parameter ::= type_name name "=" "feature" feature_name

type_name name "=" "segment" segment_name
type_name name "=" "rc_handler" handler_name
type_name name "=" "[[" java_source "]]

To give an example, here's a java_command that would cycle through the parts of an assembly if attached to a timer,
achieving an effect like an image_sequence:

java_command ( Assembly a = feature F:MyAssembly, int[] count = [[ new int[1] ]] ) [[
Feature[] parts = a.getParts(); // just an accessor, this does not copy array
if (parts.length == 0)

{ return; }

count[0]++;
if (count[0] >= parts.length)

{ count[0] = 0; }

a.setCurrentFeature(parts[count[0]]);
}

This would turn into code like this on the GrinXHelper subclass:

void someGeneratedName42() {
Assembly a = (Assembly) parameters[0];
if (parameters[1] == null)

{ // first time executing command parameters[1] = parameters; // anything non-null would do parameters[2] = new int[1]; }

int[] count = (int[]) parameters[2];
... INSERT CODE FROM SHOW FILE HERE ...
}

Note that the GRIN compiler canonicalizes the method bodies by string equivalence. In English, that means that if a
show has multiple copies of the same java_command, possibly differing in parameter values, then the GRIN compiler
will only generate the method one time, provided that the java_source elements of the commands are identical. It
doesn't understand the contents of that code, though; even white space is enough to flag a java_command as
different. This could be a little annoying for the show text file, but for automatically generated java_commands it
shouldn't be a problem.

Solving this for the text show file java_commands might involve inventing some kind of command declaration
syntax. Hmm... Maybe that's worth doing, too.
item.summary: More efficient commands and java_command parameters

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-215] Z order changes don't cause redisplay
item.description:
A change in just the Z-order of objects in a GRIN scene doesn't cause a redisplay, like it should. Such
changes are possible when:

  • Navigating to a different segment, where the active features differ only in z-order (e.g. order in the
    active clause)
  • Switching to an assembly part, where what is active differs only in z-order
  • Calling Group.resetVisibleParts() to change only the z-order of what is visible

For example, in the following show, changing the current part of the assembly in grinview does not
cause a redisplay, as it should.

show

feature box F:RedLorry ( 200 200 800 800 )
fill

{ 255 0 0 255 }

;

feature box F:YellowLorry ( 400 400 1000 1000 )
fill

{ 255 255 0 255 }

;

feature assembly F:A {
red_top sub_feature group

{ F:YellowLorry F:RedLorry }

;
yellow_top sub_feature group

{ F:RedLorry F:YellowLorry }

;
} ;

segment S:Initialize
setup

{ F:A }

setup_done

{ activate_segment S:Run ; }

;

segment S:Run
active

{ F:A }

;

end_show

This problem could be solved by adding a flag to Group (and, I guess, segment) that causes
markDisplayAreasChanged() to be called on activation. That would work, but it feels awkward. Ideally,
this change-in-z-order would be detected automatically. Maybe that's infeasible, because it involves
figuring out what's drawn over what else.

Thanks, Phil, for pointing out this problem!
item.summary: Z order changes don't cause redisplay

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Oh, to reproduce, run that show in grinview, and then click on yellow_top in the tree explorer.

OK, I guess a flag on Group and Segment would work. It could be called repaint_children_on_activate,
or maybe something more pithy. But asking authors to understand this is a burden, and it feels ugly.

Here's a sketch of an O way of doing this automatically: Use Feature.addDisplayAreas(). On the way
down the graph, give a sequential number to each draw operation (as recorded by
RenderContext.addArea()). In the same call, compare the draw operation number from the last time
around to the maximum seen so far, as recorded in the RenderContext. If it's out of order (that is, <),
the consider the new record to have changed (by calling DrawRecord.setChanged()).

A change in draw order of non-overlapping features would cause an unneeded redisplay under this
scheme, but in practice that's perhaps rare. Why would an author put things in a different order in two
different places? And, if they do, the consequences aren't that severe: Slightly less efficient drawing on
segment activation, or on assembly switch.

I think I prefer the conservative, automatic way of doing this, but still mulling, and waiting for some
feedback.

r641:

When the GRIN scene changes by having the draw order of features
change, this changes the Z-order of any overlapping features. The
animation framework's change detection algorithm didn't take this
into account, so if features changed their z-order and didn't change
position or something else, they wouldn't be re-drawn. A simple
show that reproduces the problem is included with issue 215. It can
be run with grinview to show the problem.

To fix it, we track the sequence of drawing operations, as captured by
DrawRecords. If two features are drawn in a different order than they
were in the previous frame, we make sure the entire extent of one of them
is added to the damaged area(s), and thus redrawn. We don't try to tell
if they're overlapping or not.

This could theoretically cause slower drawing in the case where the draw
order changes in a way that would have no visible effect. However, we
don't think this happens often. The draw order can change when you switch
to a new segment, or change an assembly, or change the visible parts
of a group from scripting. In order to trigger a repaint, the order would
have to be different. In a survey of about ten shows, we didn't find a single
one where the order was unintentionally different.

Just in case, we do emit a debug message (when Debug.LEVEL >= 2) if a repaint
happens because of a drawing order change. It is:

NOTE: An area of the screen is being re-drawn due to a change in z-order.
If this is unexpected, then you may get more efficient drawing if you
re-structure your show to have a consistent ordering of the features.
See also https://hdcookbook.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=215 .
This warning will not repeat.

If someone does unintentionally change the z-order (or drawing order) of
non-overlapping components, the results aren't too bad: just slightly
less efficient drawing. And, hopefully, this debug message will help out
anyone who does that, so they can make the show more efficient.

The performance impact of this extra draw-order bookkeeping should be pretty
minor. We were able to piggy-back on two loops that were already there.

By the way, this putback also includes a little fix to GrinView and the
bookmenu's grinview target. These were discovered during testing.

Code reviewed by Chihiro. Thanks, Chihiro! And thanks for pointing out
the problem, Phil!

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-214] Somewhat obscure Image.flush() deadlock
item.description:
Under certain circumstances, a call to Image.flush() blocks, while a callback in a different thread
(presumably an image fetcher) to imageUpdate() occurs. Of course, our implementation of
imageUpdate() needs to take out a lock, so this means that the ManagedFullImage lock /cannot/ be held
while Image.flush() is called. This behavior was observed on players from two major manufacturers, and
seems to be triggered by calling flush() immediately after Component.prepareImage(). This behavior
was not observed on desktop JDK (1.6); in other words, this subtle platform bug seems to have been
fixed on the desktop

ManagedFullImage should not hold the monitor while calling flush().
item.summary: Somewhat obscure Image.flush() deadlock

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

able to trigger the deadlock described in the issue; after this

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-211] Bit shifting problem in Playlist.jar's SubPlayItem
item.description:
Original bug report:

=========
The specific issue is in net.java.bd.tools.playlist.SubPlayItem#readObject() on line 119:

119: setSpConnectionCondition(b & 0x1e);

This sets the sp_connection_condition using the 4 bits from b1 to b4 (skipping b0, which is a flag for
something else). However, it forgets to shift the result >> 1 to get the actual integer value. As a
result, an sp_connection_condition of '6' shows up in the XML output as '12'. When writing the values
back out to binary form, the code does shift << 1, as it should. However, this ensures that a
conversion of binary -> XML -> binary will result in an invalid PlayList if SubPathItems are present.

The fix:

119: setSpConnectionCondition((b & 0x1e) >> 1);
=========

Planning to fix as suggested on line 119, and also to add a value check in
setSpConnectionCondition(int) method, as the sp_connection_condition's valid values are 1, 5, or 6 (BD
spec part 3-1 5.3.6.2).
item.summary: Bit shifting problem in Playlist.jar's SubPlayItem

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
r601:

Bug cloning Text features

When a setup text feature was clone, the width was copied over, but
the setupMode flag was not. This made it so that subsequent setText
operations failed to calculate the font metrics, which caused the feature's
damage rectangle to not be re-calculated. Fixed.

Profiling improvements

Added a devastatingly cool scale display to the simple PCProfiler GUI.
Put updated images in www/profiler.html.

Added constants PROFILE_ANIMATION and PROFILE_SETUP to Debug, and defaulted
them to false. These now control profiling of the animation loop and the
setup loop. This is handy if you want to turn off this profiling, but
you want profiling on to measure something else, because now you won't get
these extra UDP packets adding noise to the measurement you care about.
Also, when displaying you don't have to filter out all the animation loop
stuff.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-209] GrinXlet should load fonts according to dvb.fontindex
item.description:
GrinXlet currently doesn't load fonts. In theory, you could install the needed font on your computer, and
install it into Java, but that's a configuration change on every computer where you want to run the
GrinView version of the xlet.

A better solution would be for GrinView to detect and parse dvb.fontindex, and then use AssetManager to
call createFont(int fontFormat, InputStream fontStream).
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: GrinXlet should load fonts according to dvb.fontindex

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-206] Playlist tool IN_time/OUT_time Integer overflow
item.description:
If in or out times are later than 13:15:21:?? the exported xml will contain
negative values because Integer value is larger than 2^31-1. Value should be
32bit unsigned int (Spec 5.3.4.2).

Recommended fix for PlayItem.java:

  • declare inTime and outTime variables as long instead of int
item.summary: Playlist tool IN_time/OUT_time Integer overflow

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-201] BDCertGenerator: Enable certificate signing capability for application certificates
item.description:
The certificate chain can be generated using BDCertGenerator starting with one
root and a set of application certs signed by one another to form a chain.

But, the application certificates generated from BDCertGenerator don't have the
certificate signing extension set in them. The BDCertGenerator does not check
this extension while signing the certificates.
We have created a certificate chain this way and it works without problem on PS3.

It's probably better to add an option to the BDCertGenerator to indicate if the
given application certificate is intended to be used for signing other
certificates and set the cert_sign bit in it, while it is getting generated.

It's not required test for this extension in the signing certificate to keep it
tolerant towards application certificates that don't have this bit set but want
to sign other certificates.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-199] ManagedFullImage has unfriendly failure mode if unget precedes unprepare
item.description:
ManagedImage has two levels of referencing counting: a "prepare" count to control image loading, and
a reference count, to track how many times an image is referenced. This latter count is needed to
canonicalize ManagedImage references, that is, so that ImageManager can keep a list of all active
image instances, and thus share ManagedImage instances that refer to the same underlying image.

Using ManagedImage, the xlet should always follow this pattern:

get reference to image (incrementing reference count)
prepare the image
use it
unprepare the image
unget the image (decrementing reference count)

Currently, the failure mode if the last two steps are reversed is unfriendly. That is, if the application
ungets the image before it unprepares it, bad things happen:

1) No warning is issued
2) image.getWidth() and getHeight() are called on a java.awt.Image that has been flushed, which can
lead to re-loading the image
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh

Changed ManagedFullImage to store image width and height as instance
variables, so that image.getWidth() and image.getHeight() don't need to
be called. That way, if width and height are consulted after image.flush()
(as happens when unget precedes unprepare), there is no danger of
triggering a re-load of the image.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-197] NetworkManager thread can jump in at the app startup
item.description:
com.hdcookbook.grin.util.NetworkManager currently runs a thread with priority 5,
which is a higher priority than both the SetupManager and AnimationEngine's
painting threads. Hence the app that posts http request using NetworkManager
can appear as it "hangs" at the beginning, where the http request happens before
all the setup of a given segment is done.

I believe the effect we want with NetworkManager is that it runs in the
background while the setup and animation starts normally.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-184] Make grin runtime easier to work with downloaded show files
item.description:
This is a problem that came to our attention during an Sun internal project.
The project required GRIN runtime to deal with multiple Show files, in which
some of them are downloaded and installed after the first show has been
launched, thus after the GRIN runtime has already been running.

So far, the changes to hdcookbook are the followings:

  • The downloaded show often comes with .class files - Director subclass and
    GrinXHelper subclass, in our case. GrinBinaryReader is the one who instantiates
    these classes, so I've added a new constructor to the GrinBinaryReader that
    takes ClassLoader instance for finding the downloaded class. There is a wider
    question of whether an URLClassLoader created by an application running on a BD
    platform will have the necessary permission to instantiate the classes, but, at
    least, the API addition felt right.
  • Loading and unloading of the new show is done by the xlet, in our case
    GrinXlet's subclass. Meanwhile, there was no mechanism for GrinViewer to take
    an subclass of GrinXlet. Thus, a new command line option -grinxlet <classname>
    was added to the GrinViewer.
  • User events (RCEvent, KeyEvent, MouseEvent etc) had to be distributed to
    multiple shows. I've added pushKeyInterest(Show) and popKeyInterest() methods
    to GrinXlet, which can be used to decide the show's order in which the event
    will be delivered to. If the show is in a segment that uses a particular event,
    then the key is considered to be "consumed" by that show. The key is sent to
    the shows in order until the key gets consumed.
item.summary: Make grin runtime easier to work with downloaded show files

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-183] Grinview messes up alpha blending on Mac Intel with Java 5
item.description:
This is a bit of a mystery, but I ran Bobinsky-Grinview on my new MacBook Pro, and it wasn't doing alpha
at all. It's probably hard for anyone else to reproduce (unless they happen to have run out and bought a
new laptop recently), so I'm assigning this to myself.

billf@~$ java -version
java version "1.6.0_13"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_13-b03-211)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 11.3-b02-83, mixed mode)
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Grinview messes up alpha blending on Mac Intel with Java 5

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
FWIW, I upgraded to the latest JDK from the Apple Developer Connection, and I still see the problem. I
also ran the program under Grinview on the same PC using Windows (under VMWare), and it works fine
(i.e. no bug).

The new Mac JDK (where I still see the issue) is:
billf@~$ java -version
java version "1.6.0_15"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_15-b03-223)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 14.1-b02-92, mixed mode)

I suspect something relatively simple, like grinview incorrectly using a default parameter in a factory
method for a buffered image or something. We'll see...

Oh, it turns out I'm an idiot. I was launching the app by double-clicking a JAR, and I forgot to make my
default JDK be JDK 1.6, rather than JDK 1.5. From the command-line, I was getting JDK 1.6, because I
had my bash config (that I wrote years ago) explicitly pointing to JDK 1.6. D'oh!

Thanks to Jon for providing context.

It looks like there is a bug somewhere when JDK 1.5 is used; from descriptions, it's not clear if it's an
Apple bug in the JDK 1.5 graphics layer, or a usage bug in grinview. However, you need JDK 1.6 to
build grinview anyway, so I'm going to close this as "invalid." If someone wants to raise the issue later
of bad grinview behavior on Mac using JDK 1.5 on Intel machines, that would be a valid issue to raise
(at, say, P4), but I don't choose to raise that at this time.

I read through Apple's release notes for "Java for Mac OS X 10.5" and found this little item. Just FYI, it
looks like the JDK 5 and JDK 6 on the Mac use entirely different graphics engines by default.

Found at:
http://developer.apple.com/releasenotes/Java/JavaLeopardUpdate4RN/ResolvedIssues/ResolvedIssues.
html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40008975-CH3-SW1

—
Radar #5719903
Poor graphics fidelity, performance in J2SE 5.0.

Description:
The Sun2D renderer in J2SE 5.0 has many unaddressable performance and fidelity issues, including
poor aliased circle drawing, slow anti-aliased primitives, very slow image scaling, and occasional
crashes.

Workaround:
The Sun2D software renderer is still available via -Dapple.awt.graphics.UseQuartz=false.

Resolution:
The default graphics renderer for J2SE 5.0 has been switched back to Quartz. In Java SE 6, the quality
and the performance of the Sun2D renderer is significantly better, so the default renderer for Java SE 6
remains Sun2D.

Re-opening at P4; based on Jon's e-mail, there is a workaround that is in process. The workaround
makes grinview slow but correct when using JDK 1.5. The workaround is this:

public static void main(String[] args) {
try {
if (System.getProperty("java.version").startsWith("1.5.")
&& System.getProperty("os.name").startsWith("Mac")
&& System.getProperty("os.arch").startsWith("i386"))

{ System.setProperty("apple.awt.graphics.UseQuartz", "false"); System.out.println(); System.out.println("NOTE: Java 5 on Mac/Intel detected. Due to known issues, Quartz is being"); System.out.println(" disabled. You may wish to switch to Java 6 to get better performance."); System.out.println(" You can set your default java runtime from Applications -> Utilities"); System.out.println(" -> Java Preferences."); System.out.println(); System.out.println(" See also https://hdcookbook.dev.java.net/issues/show_bug.cgi? id=183"); System.out.println(); }

} catch (Throwable t)

{ t.printStackTrace(); }

r549:
It turns out that this is a bug in the Apple quartz library. Changed
GrinView to deteck Mac/Intel/Java 5. When it does, it issues a
message to stdout, and uses a system property to turn off Quartz and
revert to the Sun renderer. Thanks, Jon, for tracking down the
Apple issues and the system property!

Created an attachment (id=105)
Webrev of fix described above

It turns out the that for the 64-bit version of Mac JDK 5, the os.arch property is
reported as "x86_64" rather than "i386". See the next attached webrev (webrev-183-2.zip) for a fix.

Fix for Mac JDK 5 64-bit platform

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-179] AssetFinder.setImageMaps() may block
item.description:
It's been requested that AssetFinder.setImageMaps() method can potentially take

should become an asynchronous call.

Perhaps we can apply timeout (guarantee to return within certain time even if
the data hasn't been returned) just like we did for PBP 1.0's socket timeout
example?

The original request is below.
======================
If the image maps being loaded are actually located out on the network, or are
potentially stored on a damaged disc or HDD, it is possible that the
setImageMaps() call could block indefinitely (or at least for a very long time)
since it actually attempts to read map files right at that time. It seems like

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-178] AssetFinder should be thread safe
item.description:
Apparently it's becoming more common for the content to use multiple grin shows,
or have additional content that can be downloaded via BDLive. These are causing
grin's AssetFinder to be accessed by more than one thread in some cases. It's
been requested that some methods like AssetFinder.setImageMaps() be thread safe
so that concurrent access do not cause unexpected outcome.

Below is an original problem report.
============
More and more, we are beginning to work in multi-show environments in which we
have concurrent shows loading various properties and having their own search
paths, image maps, etc. However, it doesn't appear that the Asset Finder's
methods for setting image maps, in particular, was built to handle concurrent
access very well. For example, if one thread calls AssetFinder.setImageMaps()
and is quickly followed by another thread calling the same, it is possible
that there will be a conflict, typically causing only a portion of the maps
to actually get loaded. It appears similar problems can occur with other
search path related functions.
=============

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-170] Fontstrip's handling of parent fade nodes
item.description:
In http://forums.java.net/jive/thread.jspa?messageID=346112, Mirek notes
that FontStripText sets the drawing mode to have an alpha of 255, even if there
is a parent fade node that sets the alpha to something else. This raises some
interesting structural issues.

It would be good if we could take the parent alpha, and change just the drawing mode
to SRC_OVER for our draw, but the Graphics.setComposite() API's structure isn't well suited
to this. Done the simple way, we'd allocate a new AlphaComposite object every time the paint
call is made, and this runs counter to the goal of avoiding allocations in animation.

Perhaps a reasonable compromise is to only change the drawing mode if the inherited mode isn't
SRC_OVER, but when the drawing mode is changed, go ahead and use the constant
AlphaComposite.SrcOver. This does mean that a parent SRC-mode fade would have no effect,
however. It would be good if the GRIN compiler at least issued a warning in this case.

Issuing this warning is an interesting challenge, but it also forces some useful structural changes into
SENode and the GRIN compiler. One way would be to add a visitor (a bit like SEDoubleUseChecker)
would have to be run over the show, to find all of the paths from the root to any FontStripText node.
This means that the extension compiler API would have to be expanded to let extensions run their own
checker, which seems like a good and useful change.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Fontstrip's handling of parent fade nodes

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
r497:
Changed FontStripText so that it only sets the drawing mode
to AlphaComposite.SrcOver if the drawing mode isn't already
SrcOver. This way, if there's a src_over fade node above it
in the tree, it won't re-set the drawing mode with an alpha
of 255.

The text feature initialization issue is captured in issue 157.

I looked at fontstrip, and it does its setup in the setup thread like it's supposed to. It does calculate the
font metrics when reading from the binary file, but this is, in turn, just reading from a different binary file,

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-168] Tracking of image load/unload is desirable
item.description:
Today, creation of buffered images and loading of images goes through the AssetFinder gateway, which
provides a way for the xlet writer to intercept image load calls. It would be good to extend this so that
an xlet that chooses to do so could track image loading and unloading, e.g. against a model of the
capacity of the pixmap buffer.

A few slight extensions in com.hdcookbook.util would make this much easier, namely:

  • Adding AssetFinder calls when an image is queued for loading, and when it
    comes off the loading queue (which is when you know its size)
  • Adding an AssetFinder call for when an image is flushed so the xlet can track
    image unloads, and modifying ManagedFullImage to call it
  • Of course, correctly handling the corner case where image load is aborted while the
    image is queued
  • Adding a call to notify AssetManager when a BufferedImage is no longer needed so this
    can be tracked, and making DirectDrawEngine respect this new contract
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Tracking of image load/unload is desirable

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: I want to get this done before I go on vacation.

I'm not usually a big fan of subclassing, but perhaps the best way to handle the first three bullets is to
give AssetFinder factory methods for ManagedFullImage, so that an AssetFinder instance can return a
subclass (perhaps something like WatchedFullImage) that overrides the appropriate methods. There
are only two places in ImageManager that call "new ManagedFullImage" that would need to be changed
to call the factory methods.

ManagedFullImage could add a method notifyLoaded() that gets called when an image finishes coming

item.description:
The update to Security code for configuring custom password that also involved
clean up of variable names resulted in a application certificate exported as the
binding unit root certificate. This resulted in BUMF verification to fail, which

comments.comment:
More good ideas from Mark:

Allow Xlets to register a trace log listener with Grin's Debug class
and just pass the string data to that listener when debug statements
are required. That allows an Xlet to use whatever mechanism it prefers
to output the trace log statements. (Some use DVBTest, some use an
on-screen logger, others might send it over the network, etc.)

Also, an id string that mirrors the DVBTest ID string can be a good
thing, e.g. Debug could have a new method:

public void traceLog(String id, String msg);

r487:
Tracked down the many places where xlet code called Throwable.printStackTrace(),
and replaced them with Debug.printStackTrace(Throwable). This is important,
because at least one player handles printing to System.err (as is done by
Throwable.printStackTrace()) very slowly. Also, found one or two places
where xlet code was using System.out or System.err directly; these were
replaced with Debug calls.

Added a bunch of explanation to the library version of com.hdcookbook.grin.util.Debug,
and referred to in in the debug and deploy versions of this source file that
exist in GrinXlet. Also, added an obnoxious message to the library version of
Debug, to make sure people don't deploy this by mistake. The message refers
to the Debug class documentation.
============================================

About the trace log listener: See the comments in Debug.java. Making a listener is
a great idea, but the design choices made in hdcookbook mean that you're pretty
much guaranteed of needing to replace Debug.java anyway (either to swap in different
versions, as GrinXlet does, or to have the build edit the file to change the values of
ASSERT and LEVEL). While you're swapping out and/or editing Debug.java, it's not hard
to also change method implementations, e.g. to add a listener.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-161] "Flash" when a segment's setup clause does real loading
item.description:
#

  1. This show demonstrates a bug with GRIN setup, where a segment that
  2. has a setup clause that causes actual loading will fail to display
  3. until the loading is complete. To reproduce, run this show using
  4. any image you have lying around as im0.png. Set the framerate to
  5. something low, like 0.5, then click on S:One. After it displays,
  6. click on S:Two. You'll see that the screen goes blank for at least
  7. one frame, resulting in a flash effect.
    #

show

feature text F:one left 200 top 200 "One" SansSerif plain 80
{

{ 255 255 255 255 } } ;

feature text F:two left 200 top 200 "Two" SansSerif plain 80
{ { 255 255 255 255 }

} ;

feature fixed_image F:Image 0 0 im0.png ;

segment S:One
active

{ F:one }

setup

{ F:one F:two }

;

segment S:Two
active

{ F:two }

setup

{ F:one F:two F:Image }

;

end_show

The problem seems to be related to showTop, and the optimization of setup... The show top's group
doesn't have its active features set to the segment's active features until all loading is complete. It
should be set as soon as the active features' loading is complete. In a correctly structured show, this
will happen immediately.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-158] FontStrip optimizations
item.description:
I noticed that some heap garbage is generated when rendering a font strip, here:

charInfo = (CharImageInfo) charMap.get(new Character(chars[i]));

That could be optimized away pretty easily, by recording the CharImageInfo for each character
in a CharImageInfo[].

Another possibility would be to make a perfect hash table for CharImageInfo. Generating a perfect
hash table takes some time in the compiler, but if that were done the hash table lookup becomes some
fast arithmetic, and then a table lookup in a global CharImageInfo[]. A quick google on "perfect hash
table" revealed this article, which looks promising:

http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2001/01/25/hash_functions.html

In the case of looking up CharImageInfo, we have a much easier job than, say, gperf (which generates a
perfect hash table of strings) - in our case, the key is a 16 bit int. It might even make sense to have
the compiler figure out a minimal perfect hash function (I see the onjava.com article references a Dr.
Dobbs article on this subject).
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: FontStrip optimizations

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
Created an attachment (id=89)
r478 webrev

Partially addressed by r478:
This is a pretty simple putback that spends 4 bytes/character in
order to avoid allocating a bunch of heap objects each time font
strip text is displayed. Originally we weren't to worried about
this, since we expected font strip text to be stationery most
of the time, but there have now been reports of wanting to animate
font strip text, too.

More could be done here: The perfect hash speedup mentioned in
the issue is alluring, and for strings known at compile time, there's
no real reason to not generate the CharMapInfo[][] at compile time,
and just record it as a bunch of integer indexes into an array
maintained while reading the binary file.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-156] Standard extension to render into a (scalable) image
item.description:
Sometimes called "blit stretch," it's useful to have a node that renders its children into an image, so that
the result can have arbitrary scale factors applied to it. This lets one e.g. render text into a buffered
image, then e.g. fake "2 1/2 D" rotation via creative scaling. Adding a node like this shouldn't be in the
GRI?N core, but it would be a reasonable thing to add as a standard GRIN extension.

It's probably worth making it so that a number of such nodes share one underlying BufferedImage
(using different parts of the BufferedImage, in a mosaic-like way). Remember, too, that two such
nodes can share some part of the area of that BufferedImage if it can be guaranteed that those two
nodes are never simultaneously active.

Sharing the image buffer obviously causes complications for cloning; that has to be thought through
(or just avoided e.g. by not allowing the clones to share the image).
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Standard extension to render into a (scalable) image

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
Thinking about this a bit more...

This is useful for caching reasons, too. Measurements indicate that drawing time has more to do with
the number of drawing operations than with the area drawn to. The means that if a scene is composed
of a number of small images (like a font strip, or items in a game), and that composition is animated by
moving it around or fading it in and out, drawing speed could be increased by doing the draw once, to
a single BufferedImage, and then just re-drawing that BufferedImage in one operation.

This would of course have the semantic effect of setting a clip around its children (i.e. the dimensions
of the BufferedImage).

This node would have to interject itself into the damage rect calculation. If any of its children cause
damage, that part of the buffered image would need to be redrawn. In theory, one could do the whole
optimized draw calculation for the children of this node, but it's much simpler (and probably better in
most cases) to just have one damage rect for all of the children. After all, this image buffer shouldn't
be too big.

It wouldn't make sense to have a set_target under such a buffered image node. This constraint should
be enforced in the GRIN compiler with a checker.

Attached as test_with_fontstrip.zip is a GRIN show using fontstrip that would be a good test of this
feature. It would be interesting to measure the performance of this with and without the BufferedImage
pixel cache. In this test xlet, we have a clipped feature. When the extension is written, just change this
to a feature whose type is the extension.

Created an attachment (id=98)
A demo xlet where a pixmap cache would speed things up

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-152] key typed events
item.description:
Key typed events aren't a required part of GEM, but they can exist in a BD/GEM context:

o An external keyboard might generate them
o An external keyboard might generate key_pressed and key_released events that can be
synthesized by an xlet in to key released events
o A virtual keyboard might be a part of an xlet

If there is a viable source of key typed events, it could be useful to use the GRIN framework for dispatch of
remote control events for these events, too. A couple of tweaks here and there make GRIN extensible in
this way.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-151] JSON parsing and writing
item.description:
A simple JSON library in com.hdcookbook.grin.util (or maybe com.hdcookbook.util?) would be a good
thing to have. The JSON syntax is very simple, and presented with a funny Pascal-ish syntax diagram
at http://json.org/. The "library" would basically be two methods:

Object read(DataInputStream) throws IOException

void write(DataOutputStream, Object) throws IOException

There's no good reason I can see to invent a new type hierarchy - the JSON types map directly as
follows:

JSON TYPE -> Java Type

Object -> HashSet
Array -> Object[]
String -> String
Number -> java.lang.Number (subclass determined by value)
true/false -> Boolean
null -> null

It's OK to put this in the "GRIN core" location without worrying about code bloat, since this is very small,
and obfuscators should be smart enough to strip out unused methods anyway.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-150] Browser for Profiling Data
item.description:
Now that we can produce profiling data, it would be good to build a simple graphical browser of that
data so it can be interpreted. Here's one possibility...

Based on the time values, it should be pretty easy to construct a call graph for the timing probes: If
the times of a method call fall completely inside the times of another, it's "inside" that call. This, of
course, ignores concurrency. For most BD-J xlets that can be OK, except perhaps for initialization
(which happens on a separate thread). Still, for completeness, we probably should add at least a
"task_id" byte to the start_timer record... This could be passed in as a parameter by the programmer.
(Another alternative would be to derive a thread_id, but that's not so easy, and sometimes you want to
consider things that happen on different Java threads as the same "task" anyway).

Anyway, with a call graph, one could make a hierarchical browsing UI, using the same Swing widget
that GrinView uses. It would be organized by timer ID, with "child" timers beneath it in the hierarchy.
Of course, the top of the tree would be the task_id values discussed above. When one clicks on a timer,
one could get the mean, median and standard deviation of the timer values, along with maybe a
histogram. It would be nice if one could scroll around and scale the histogram.

I looked around for freeware for making graphs - jfree.org looks promising. OTOH, making a
histogram from scratch isn't all that hard either.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Browser for Profiling Data

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Task ids are already generated aren't they?
For example, in the code snippet below PROFILE_TIMER_1 and PROFILE_TIMER_2 are
two task ids that identify loading and running of a JavaFX test.

static {
if (Debug.PROFILE)

{ PROFILE_TIMER_1 = Debug.makeProfileTimer("JavaFX Test loading"); PROFILE_TIMER_2 = Debug.makeProfileTimer("JavaFX Test run"); }

}

If I interpret the description right, a task id means a series of method calls
involved in getting a specific task done. In that case I'm not sure if
makeProfileTimer() is the right method for creating task ids. This may have to
be added.

Partially addressed with a crude initial prototype (r494):
This putback adds a Crude, prototype profiling data capture &
display program. It displays in a GUI, but it's command-line
driven. We expect that this will be substantially revised in
the future; this version is just good enough to do some
exploration and make some slides for a JavaOne talk.

Also Added a thread ID argument for profiling. Put profiler calls in
a few key places in the animation manager and in the setup manager.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-149] QHD debug screen would be nice
item.description:
In the about-to-be-checked-in TwitterXlet, the player's screen resolution is set to QHD. It works fine, but
the debug screen comes out wrong, obviously. It would be nice to have a QHD version. This could
probably be done adequately by having the grin compiler automatically make a scaled-down .grin file.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: QHD debug screen would be nice

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Moving this up to P2, since scaling to different screen sizes becomes more important in OCAP-land.

Of course, for any really nice screen, one would probably want to invest in graphics design to make the
best use of each resolution, but for quick projects and for things like the debug screen, auto-scaling a
.grin file would be quite handy.

Looking into this more deeply, a few areas need to be changed. A good way of testing this would be to
make a QHD version of GrinBunny. This requires a few changes:

  • A "-scale <num>" argument passed into the GRIN show compiler
  • An interface (SEFeatureExtensions) that can be implemented by features
    that support extensions, like scaling. If a show is scaled and a feature doesn't
    support SEFeatureExtensions, then compilation can fail.
  • If scaling down, the mosaic builder should reduce the images by that scale factor.
  • Fontstrip needs to support a -scale argument too, so these fonts can be reduced in size.
  • The scale factor (in mills, presumably) needs to be available in Show at runtime, so the
    director can do the right thing.

I think it's better to force the director to consider scaling, rather than (say) trying to build it into
InterpolatedModel at runtime.

r520:

<no issue # - fixing recent regressions>

Fixed a setup bug in text feature where setup wasn't happening properly
if script called Text.setText before the text feature was setup. This
could have caused setup_done to not be triggered.

Restored Text.getFont() method that was taken away in recent putback.
It is needed by xlets, e.g. to calculate font metrics. Indeed, this
is done in twitterGRIN.

Issue 149: Scaling shows at compile time ("QHD debug screen would be nice")

Implemented compile-time scaling of GRIN shows, so a full HD show can be
automatically scaled down to 720p HD, or QHD, or even SD. Tested by
making a new version of GrinBunny that runs at different scales,
in xlets/tests/functional/ScaleBunny.

In the grin compiler, created new SEScalableNode interface, to be implemented
by all RC handlers and features that support scaling. Implemented scaling in
GRIN core nodes, e.g. by scaling down the placement of images. For Text,
just scaled down the font size - there's no way to fix the aspect ratio
when xScale != yScale. In the GRIN compiler, scaling is done as a pass
toward the end. If any of the show's nodes aren't scalable, and a scale
factor (other than 1.0) is being applied, then compilation fails.

Made box so that at runtime it supports different widths for the horizontal
and vertical lines. This is needed for scaling that changes the pixel
aspect ratio.

Implemented scaling in the visual RC handler by changing the rectangle
used for mouse support.

In the mosaic compiler, made it look at the images, and the placements of
all of the features that use the images. If the placement is smaller than
the source image, reduce the size of the image what's needed by the features,
thus making for smaller matrixes when scaling is done.

Added Show.scale(), Show.getXScale(), Show.getYScale(), Show.getXOffset()
and Show.getYOffset() for use by directors. Generally, directors should
never get coordinates from a scaled show - they should maintain them as
instance variables, sized to the "native" screen size of the xlet (probably
full HD). If they do this, and then scale those coordinates every time
they set a coordinate in the show, all will be well when things are scaled.

Changed the font strip support so that the character metrics are closer to
what's needed for rendering, rather than being based on coordinates in the
design image. This is equivalently efficient at runtime, but in the new
form it's easier to know what to scale by which scale factor in the compiler.
Implemented scaling of fontstrips in the font strip compiler.

Implemented GRIN compiler scaling in SEFontStrip. Note that it expects, but
does not enforce the same scaling factor between the two compilers.

Added ScaleBunny show to scale the grin bunny game to 720 HD, QHD, and SD.

Implemented debug.screen.scale property in GrinXlet, so that the debug screen
can be scaled down. Used this new property in weatherWidget and twitterXlet,
so now the debug screen is sized for the screen configuration.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-145] A mechanism for profiling xlets
item.description:
A framework for execution time profiling on the real players is very much
desirable. A generic profiling framework comes in very handy in proving with
real numbers the feasibility of using more attractive development environments
such as JavaFX, JavaScript for BD-J development.

It's really hard to get good profiling data for a BD application.
As BD-Live players become more prevalent, and on OCAP where
all players are networked, we might want to think about technologies for
doing execution time profiling of xlets involving Network.
item.summary: A mechanism for profiling xlets

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
A good mechanism for this might be to use an accurate clock on a PC for the timing. This could be
done by sending UDP packets from the device under test. The API for this on the xlet side could
naturally fit into com.hdcookbook.grin.util.Debug, and might look like this:

void aMethodOfInterest() {
int id = Debug.startTiming("aMethodOfInterest");
try

{ ... execute aMethodOfInterest body }

finally

{ Debug.endTiming(id); }

}

Debug.startTiming and Debug.endTiming would just assign sequential IDs, and send a UDP packet to
the PC.

BTW, in the future we could even think of using bytecode editing to inject this kind of code into an xlet
under test... but that's complicated, and hand-editing in the profiling code is pretty easy.

Another thought, courtesy of Joe Rice: The method javax.media.Player. getMediaNanoseconds() could be
used when media is playing in order to get a sufficiently accurate clock to time methods. This has the
advantage of working on profile 1 and 1.1 players (that is, players without internet connections) - the
method times could be stored in memory, and then after the test some code could run to write out the
results to the debug log, or even to present bar graphs and such. We think getMediaNanoseconds()
should have a 45 KHz resolution, that is, a granularity of 22 microseconds. This should be checked (e.g.
by polling the value and seeing how much it changes by when it changes). Joe sez part 3-2 14.10 talks
about this.

The current fix adds a mechanism for profiling on a remote computer.
The latter solution of using javax.media.Player.getMediaNanoseconds()
for a non-networked player needs to be considered.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-143] Image cloning bug
item.description:
See attached program to re-create - instructions in README.txt

Here's the situation

Segment1 -> setup FixedImage F1; call F1.replaceImage with a new ManagedImage; setup FixedImage
F2
Segment2 -> activate F2; setup Group G1 and F1 (for Segment3) and in java_command clone F1 and
add clone to G1
Segment3 -> activate G1, resulting in activate clone of F1, which crashes

My diagnosis:
When F1 is setup, FixedImage.imageSetup is set to true and FixedImage.image is prepared, etc.
When F1.replaceImage is called with a new ManagedImage, the original FixedImage.image is unloaded,
as it should be
When F1.createClone is called, result.image is set to ImageManager.getImage(fileName), which is at this
point unloaded
BUT, we set result.imageSetup to true, which is inconsistent.

Proposed fix (which I am by no means certain of)
In FixedImage.createClone set result.image = ImageManager.getImage(image.getName()); which we are
certain is currently loaded, etc.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Image cloning bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Created an attachment (id=77)
Program to re-create bug

r459:
Fix for issue 143, "Image Cloning Bug"

There were two bugs here. The first was that cloned features need to
do the equivalent of setup/unsetup. This only comes up with images
(of course), and it doesn't show up if the feature you're cloned
from stays active. The fix was to do a prepare() of the ManagedImage
in the cloned feature when it's created, and a balanced unprepare()
when it's destroyed.

The second bug was an interaction betwen FixedImage.replaceImage()
and cloning a fixed image feature. The clone method was using the name
of the original image, rather than the image that replaced it; this was
fixed.

Added a regression test for the first of these bugs to Playground.

the needed lifecycle for the first bug.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-141] Remote control handling improvements (commands)
item.description:
The remote control key handling could be improved. Today, the AWT input thread has to take out a
show lock in order to deliver an RC event. Normally it can 24 times a second, which is plenty, but a
system plagued by slow model updates might run into trouble, particularly on a (hypothetical, and not
observed in practice) player that doesn't respect the higher thread priority that the AWT input thread
should have.

Instead, a purely local lock could be taken out, to queue RC key events for the show. Because the Show
method returns a boolean stating whether the event was used or not, we'd have to pre-compute which
keys are used by each segment. Also, a show boolean, use_all_rc_events would be useful, to instruct a
show to use all of the (defined) RC key events. This allows a show to capture everything, including in
the (rare) case where an event isn't used by the current segment, but is used by the segment the show
will be in when the event is processed.

While doing this, it would be nice to make the key event that triggered command execution available
somehow, e.g. through a method on the show.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Remote control handling improvements (commands)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
"use_all_rc_events" is, I think, a bad idea. It would really belong on segment, and it's easy to get the same
behavior with a single command RC handler that takes all keys, and has an empty body.

r420 (see issue 137 for webrev attachment):

This is a moderately complex putback. It is completely
backwards-compatible with exist projects, but it includes
changes to the .grin binary file format, a significant
new feature ("named commands"), and a structural change to
how remote control keypresses are handled.

Issue 137, "Named GRIN commands"

Added named commands in shows, via these public interfaces:

Show.getNamedCommand(String) to look one up
named_command in show file to create one
run_named_command in show file to run one

This provides a facility to declare a command (or a list of commands), and
give it a name. This can be used to declare a set of commands in the show
file, where it's natural to do so, and then use them on a show (via
Show.runCommand(Command)) from Java code, which can be in any thread.
This can also be handy when there are multiple shows, since Java code
in the director can be under the control of one show, but queue commands
to another.

Issue 141, "Remote control handling improvements (commands)"

Made Show so that it only takes out a local lock when it processes
remote control key press and release events. These events are now
queued like commands, and executed in the animation loop.

Issue 99, "Canonicalize more stuff in the GRIN binary writer"

Now, command instances and command arrays are canonicalized.
Extension commands need to override equals(Object) and hashCode()
if they want to be canonicalized, of course.

The GRIN binary file size remains about the same, but the runtime
memory footprint should go down, particularly since simple, command
command arrays are shared. This is particularly true if there are
many empty command arrays, or command arrays that only contain a
single command like segment_done.

Reviewed by Chihiro

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-140] BDJO generator gives cryptic error message on parse error
item.description:
When presented with an invalid BDJO file, the BDJO generator gives an error message that's pretty darn cryptic. It's at the
end of this description, but basically it gives the line number, hidden under something about
"DefaultValidationEventHandler", and the misleading message "invalid file," but it doesn't say the name of the file that's
invalid, or the field in the file that has the syntax error. Then it gives a long exception with a bunch of reflective-looking
stuff that doesn't help users of the tool.

At a minimum, we should catch the syntax error, and present a more friendly message with some whitespace around it, at
the end of the message (i.e. after the exception), so people running ant will see it. It would be nice if the XML parser gave
a better message, too, maybe saying "syntax error in file" rather than "invalid file", and maybe saying which field had the

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-139] Add translate/clip (and other effects) to a show's top level
item.description:
There's a need to be able to add a position and a clipping to the top level of a show. This lets one stack shows on top
of eachother, while respecting a "windowing" behavior, where things outside of the show's bounding box don't show
up. Picking up from an e-mail exchange...

It occurs to me, this is basically equivalent to putting
a little show graph subtree at the top of every segment. consisting
of a translation and a clip. I think
something more powerful could be build that achieves more code
reuse by building something out of the existing code. We could slightly
extend the syntax to allow you to put any scene graph you want
at the top of a show, with one blank place where the show's current
segment gets slotted in. Something like:

feature show_current_segment F:MyShow.Body ;

  1. This gives a name to the "slot" where the current
  2. segment's active features go

feature clipped F:MyShow.Clip F:MyShow.Body
( 0 0 499 499 ) ; # Show clipped to this rectangle

feature translator_model F:MyShow.Pos

{ 200 500 }

; # Show is positioned at 200, 500, and can be

  1. moved programmatically if you want

feature translator F:MyShow F:MyShowTop.Pos

{ F:MyShow.Pos F:MyShow.Clip }

;

show_top F:MyShow ;

  1. When the show is displayed, the top of the scene graph will be
  2. F:MyShow, with the current segment's active features slotted in
  3. at F:MyShow.Body

In the implementation, F:MyShow.Body would be an empty group,
and on switching segments I'd use Group.resetVisibleParts()
to swap in the segment's active features.

One nice thing about this is that you could add a fade node to the
"show top", or a boundary around the show, or a bug... And you could
arrange for any boundary or other drawing to be either over or under
the "real" show's drawing from the current segment, too. The "show top"
could be arbitrarily complex, and even use assemblies to create effects,
or alternate decorations.

I'm not sure if I like the name "show_current_feature," but I also can't
think of anything better off the top of my head.

I think I would require that there be exactly zero or one show_current_segment,
though. That simplifies the code in Show, without losing any expressive
power.

There's no need for a special method to export the show_top from the show... Clients don't
actually care about the show_top node anyway. They care about the manipulable nodes
within that show top (like F:MyShow.Pos in the above example). The easiest way to do that is
to just export these features from the show, and to grab them with Show.getFeature(String).

Adding a mechanism to specify the top node for a rendering tree in the show file.
===============
This commit introduces two new elements in the text show syntax.

show_top ::= "show_top" string ;

  1. Sets the name of show's top node for rendering.
  2. The string should correspond to one of the feature names
  3. in this show. When the show_top element is present, then
  4. a showtop_group feature should also be defined in the show.
  5. This can be used to add a special effect to the show tree.

showtop_group :: "feature" "showtop_group" name ";"

  1. This can be used to give a name to the group of features
  2. that represents a set of active features at runtime.
  3. When a segment in this show is activated, it's active features
  4. get slotted into this group. See also "show_top".

If these elements are not present in the Show file description, then
both showtop_group and show_top feature will point to an initially empty,
anonymous Group. At show runtime, when a new segment is activated,
the ShowTop Group's part gets swapped with the segment's active features
using Group.resetVisibleParts(Feature[]).

In the Show implementation, ShowTop is represented as a Segment with
only one element in it's activated Feature array, which is the show_top feature.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-138] Optimized drawing and off-screen animations
item.description:
One common technique used in games is to position something that should be invisible off-screen.
That doesn't cause AWT any problems, since it clips all drawing to the screen or buffer being drawn to,
but it does make the animation framework create a larger damage rectangle than is necessary.

One solution would be to always clip DrawRecord drawing requests to the buffer being drawn to, but
this would add overhead. A programmer who really wants this behavior can always put a "clipped"
feature above anything that might be positioned off-screen, and doing this doesn't add too much
unnecessary overhead when drawing. Given this, for GRIN perhaps a good tradeoff is to:

  • Document that drawing optimization doesn't clip to the buffer,
    and suggest that a clipped feature be used where needed.
  • Add a special OFFSCREEN value to translator (like
    Integer.MIN_VALUE), and special-case that value with
    a low-overhead check.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-137] Named GRIN commands
item.description:
It would be good to add named commands to the GRIN text file format. This would allow something
like:

command C:MyCommand

{ activate_segment S:MySegment; java_command [[ getDirector().myPlaylist.stop(); ]] }

In other parts of the show file, this command (really command list) could be used, maybe by saying
"run C:MyCommand". But the real reason to have this is so that Java code on another thread, like the
network thread, can call into GRIN-land with java_command code declared in the GRIN file, and have
that code execute on the animation thread, by doing this:

Command c = show.getCommand("C:MyCommand");
show.runCommand(c);

(of course, doing the lookup once at startup would be recommended)

This is related to issue 122, "GrinBunny should have a star field" – a media playback extension risks
creating a temptation for a number of command types, but by adding this kind of named commands,
one can hopefully push the needed functionality into java_command objects that call methods on the
playlist object. This wouldn't require any new command subclasses.

queued like commands, and executed in the animation loop.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-134] Animation framework and falling behind in nextFrame()
item.description:
As it stands, the animation framework assumes that any computational work on the logical model of an
enhancement will take very much less than one frame's time to execute. That is, when it calls
nextFrame(), it assumes that the duration of that call will be much less than the time available to draw
one frame. This is usually a quite safe assumption; GRIN scene graphs aren't that complicated, and the
computations they do are extremely simple. Because this was viewed as a safe assumption, the
framework just calls nextFrame() for every frame, without worrying about how far behind it is.

It is possible for user code (e.g. for a game) to be in the nextFrame() calculation, and that code might
be slow for some reason. In this case, the framework can detect that it's behind. It has no mechanism
to skip frames, because the contract is that nextFrame() is called for every frame. So, it can't skip
frames, but it can reset its internal clock, in effect pausing long enough for the logical model to catch
up. This would mean that an animation would freeze for a frame or two, then resume from where it
was rather than catching up.

If this happens, the framework could also make available to user code (via a query method on the
framework) the time duration of the freeze. I don't think that a GRIN scene graph should consult this;
that would lead to many complex issues that would have to be worked out. However, a time-based
game could meaningfully consult such a value and take corrective action.

Note, however, that entering into such a pause in the first place is likely to be a sign that something is
wrong with the program using GRIN – overly time-consuming code doesn't belong in the animation
loop in the first place. So, if a "freeze" ever happens, it would be appropriate to emit a warning to the
debug log.

Platform: Macintosh

r412:
skip a frame. If the model update took at least 50% of the time allocated
to updating a frame, then instead of skipping a frame, make the model run
slower by re-setting our internal clock.

Typically, this should have no effect, because typically any model updates will
be a small fraction of the time spent animating. However, if the model
updates for some reason take much too long, the system will now degrade
more gracefully, with the overall animation appearing to slow down in this
exceptional case. In the normal case on a slow player, frames will continue
to be dropped and the model will go at normal speed.

Added AnimationEngine.getModelTimeSkipped() so an AnimationClient can
discover any model time skipped in nextFrame(). This won't be used by

Enhanced algorithm with r415:

Implement a "models on probation" algorithm.

Refined the algorithm for giving up and changing the clock when model
updates are slow. Now, a model that is slow is put on "probation,"
and is only slowed down if it's slower than a threshold value for a
second time before animation catches up. This way, an otherwise
well-behaved model that has one bad frame will continue to run at
full speed until it catches up, at which time it will be taken
off "probation."

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-133] Enhanced tree processing in GRIN compiler
item.description:
Right now, the GRIN show file compilation process is split into these phases:

1. Parsing/tree building
2. Resolving forward references (in three passes, I think, plus additional passes for extensions)
3. Tree consistency check (the double-use checker)

It would be useful to add a step just before the tree consistency check. This would let extensions do
operations on the tree, which has been found to be a useful thing for certain GRIN extensions. This
could be enabled by having the parser to a depth-first traversal of the tree, calling a new method
called SENode.postProcessTree() on each node. The iteration over the tree would need to be
modification-safe since one of the reasons to do this is to modify the tree structure. A good, simple
rule would be that the set of tree nodes to visit is computed and stored before the first tree node is
visited, and thus every node in the original tree would be visited exactly once, and not nodes added to
the tree would be visited.

Some other things that would be useful:

  • A method called SENode.injectParent(SENode), that interposes a new node between the current
    node and its parent.
  • SENode.getDescendants() that gives an iterator over all the descendants of a node
  • SENode.visitChildren() (I think that's already there, though!)
  • The ability for an extensions parser to provide a subclass of SEDoubleUseChecker that
    understands extension node types.

What makes the latter interesting is the rather unique role of assemblies – normally, the children of
any node must be disjoint, but since an assembly only has one child active at a time, its children need
not be. It's conceivable that an extension might want to have this property, too. OTOH, the method
SENode.injectParent() maybe makes it more likely that composition using SEAssembly would work as an
approach instead, but still, extending SEDoubleUseChecker makes sense logically, and is an easy bit of
extensibility to add.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-132] Add include directive
item.description:
An include directive is useful enough to want it in the text file format. It probably shouldn't be just a
textual thing like #include, though, since that can lead to very complex usages... Rather, it can be a
syntactic element, like:

show ::= "show" setting* [ exports ] [ java_generated_class ]
(segment | feature | rc_handler | mosaic_hint | include_directive )*
"end_show"

where include_directive provides a file to read from, and that file only includes show elements
(segment, feature, rc_handler or mosaic_hint).

composed, and reasonably worked on by multiple developers. With that said, we think there may be
more work that needs to be done to really properly allow for a separation of concerns divided among
different files that go into producing a .grin binary file.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-131] The fun can be halted by clones
item.description: The attached xlet generates a runtime error when a certain graph structure involving assemblies is cloned.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: The fun can be halted by clones

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Created an attachment (id=70)
Simple xlet that reproduces the problem

OK, I understand the problem. The issue is this: Consider an assembly that has this structure:

A — "one" feature X
"two" feature X

That is to say, an assembly has two assembly parts, and both parts are the same. In this case, when the
assembly is cloned, it should only make one clone of feature X, and each assembly part should share
the same cloned part instance.

More generally, the children of an assembly should share cloned parts amongst themselves. This
requires tracking the clones of each child of the assembly, and sharing them as appropriate.

The problem has been reproduced as test #6 in Playground, which uses this show structure:

feature text F:AC.Text
left 200 top 200

{ "If you see this, it worked. Press enter." }

SansSerif plain 72 {

{ 0 255 0 255 }

}
background

{ 0 0 0 255 }

;

feature assembly F:AC.Assembly

{ first F:AC.Text second F:AC.Text }

;

feature group F:AC.ClonedGroup {
} ;

F:AC.Assembly is cloned, and displayed within F:AC.CloneGroup. This causes an assertion failure, as
long as every insertion into the clones map is preceded by an (obviously valid) that there isn't already a
map entry for the key... So that assertion has been added before each such insertion.

r411:
This issue centers around cloning assemblies... The issue is that the
children of an assembly need not be disjoint, but the old cloning
algorigthm was assuming that the children of all features were disjoint.
OK, that last sentence is kind of dense... Assemblies often share nodes
between their parts. In the simplest example, consider an assembly with
two parts, where each part referred to the same FixedImage. If you clone
the assembly, you want to end up with two nodes, and assembly and a
fixed image, in that configuration. Under the old algorithm, however,
the same FixedImage feature would get cloned twice, with one clone the
first child of the cloned assembly, and the second FixedImage being
the child of the second part of the assembly. More generally, the
shared descendants of the assembly could be any number of levels
down in the tree (which is really a directed acyclic graph). So...

First Change
------------

Split Feature.makeNewClone() into makeNewClone() and createClone().
makeNewClone() made final, and made so that it checks if the given
feature has already been cloned; if so, it returns that clone. If not,
it calls the protected method createClone(). createClone() needs to be
overridden by features that support cloning. It's much like the old
makeNewClone(), EXCEPT that Feature.makeNewClone() is now responsible
for adding features to the HashSet

*****************************************

  • BACKWARDS COMPATIBILITY WARNING *
    *****************************************

Any GRIN clients who made cloneable extension features will get
a compile-time error, because they'll have overridden
Feature.makeNewClone(), which is now final. They should
change it to createClone(), make it protected, and remove code
that adds any new child clones to the HashSet(). This latter is
ensured by an assertion in Feature.makeNewClone().

Second change
-------------

Fixed up Feature.addSubgraph() to eliminate a potential O(n^2)
in the presence of assemblies. This could have manifested in
Feature.destroyClonedSubgraph(). The fix is to just check if a
feature is already in the set before adding itself and its children.

Third change
------------

Added a well-formedness assertion to Group: Each child of a group
should have a disjoint set of children from every other child. This
is assured for normal GRIN scene graphs by SEDoubleUseChecker in the
compiler, but this property was not checked for Group when
resetVisibleParts() was called, e.g. to display clones. Added an
assertion to this effect.

Fourth change
-------------

Added a regression test to Playground for issue 131.

Reviewed by and (Nizar and Chihiro)

r411 webrev

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-119] FontStrip feature should support kerning table
item.description:
Currently the FontStrip extension feature (issue 94) lets the application to
specify additional horizontal and vertical padding to be applied uniformly to a
text. This can be used to control the density of characters in a block of text.

Meanwhile, fonts can also have kerning. In FontStrip, there should be a way to
record and reproduce this spacing info that are applicable to only certain
subset of char-pairs in a font. When rendering all upper- and lowercase
alphabet char-pair, I saw that less than 7% of the system fonts that jdk found
on my PC had some occurrence of character positioning that was different from
standard font metrics positioning calculation. These font's kerning info
(char-pair and position difference) should be recorded, so that FontStrip
extension can render the char images at the position just like they will be from
the actual font files.

If the kerning occurs frequently in a particular font, then the amount of data
that needs to be carried for that font in the font strip file gets larger, and
the use of that font strip text at runtime will be slower.

The kerning will probably be an approximation. The font image generator tool
can optionally generate this kerning info in a human readable manner so that the
designer can inspect it and adjust if needed. The adjusted kerning info will
then gets fed into the fontstrip image's info file, so that it can be used for
the xlet runtime.
item.summary: FontStrip feature should support kerning table

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-111] Allow signing of a jar file with slightly different compression rate
item.description:
Reported by a user of hdcookbook's DiscCreationTools/security tool.

BDSigner has an option called "-original-only", which can be used on a jar file
that's only partially signed. This option takes a jar which only a portion of
files within are listed in META-INF's manifest, and re-sign only the files that
were originally signed.

There's been a report that a particular jar file of a user is having a problem
with this use, with an exception that looks similar to the one below.

==================
java.util.zip.ZipException: invalid entry compressed size (expected 7183 but got
7186 bytes)
at java.util.zip.ZipOutputStream.closeEntry(Unknown Source)
at java.util.zip.ZipOutputStream.putNextEntry(Unknown Source)
at java.util.jar.JarOutputStream.putNextEntry(Unknown Source)
at net.java.bd.tools.security.SecurityUtil.signOriginalJarFile(SecurityU
til.java:1093)
at net.java.bd.tools.security.SecurityUtil.signJars(SecurityUtil.java:39
8)
at net.java.bd.tools.security.BDSigner.main(BDSigner.java:130)
==================

Upon closer investigation, it appears that the jar in question was compressed
with a slightly different zip algorithm. Hence, when doing a copy from the
original jar file to a new jar file, some of it's JarEntry's recorded
compressedData field did not match with the data size that java's actual
compression operation yielded, and triggered exception.

Cloning the original JarEntry and resetting the clone's compression data size
field, and doing a entry compression to the new JarEntry instead, seem to
eliminate the problem. The user verifies that the content and the CRC32 of each
file is unchanged before and after the copy.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-109] Want extension classes to work without java_generated_class
item.description:
The mechanism for instantiating extension features and commands relies on the show defining a
java_command_class. This complicates the xlet build process somewhat, because it means that the
.java file generated by the GRIN compiler needs to be compiled and linked in with the xlet. Of course,
having a java_command_class is also necessary when a show uses java_command, but there is a class
of xlet author who is unlikely to use java_command.

In order to simplify the build process in this case, it would be nice of the .grin file could contain the
information needed to instantiate extension features and commands, without needing a
java_command_class. When this is done, it would be appropriate for the grin compiler to issue a
warning, giving the class names that must be preserved if the xlet is obfuscated. (With
java_generated_class, obfuscation is not an issue, since the obfuscator can modify the generated class,
too).

Additionally, there should be a way to specify that a .grin file have the extension .grn, since BD's local
storage only guarantees 8.3 filenames, and not all grin files are stored in JARs.

Platform: Macintosh

class is used.

compiler generates, which makes it possible to generate a binary
