item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-108] GrinView deadlock when watching drawing
item.description:
There's a simple deadlock that's possible with GrinView when watching drawing. GrinView stops the
animation thread when the Show is in a state where it can't accept keypresses. If a keypress directed at
the show comes in at that time (in the window displaying the show), then that halts the AWT thread,
making it impossible to push the button in the GrinView UI that advances the show.

This can be fixed by making a separate thread that handles AWT events sent to the show under test.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: GrinView deadlock when watching drawing

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: This is easy to fix, so I'm bumping up the priority

To reproduce, run grinview on any show, check "watch drawing," press "next" until
you see "To be erased areas shown with red overlay," wave the mouse over the
screen where the show is displayed, and click "next".

r514 (see r514_webrev.zip in issue 153 for webrev of changes):

Made GrinView so it posts a command to the show under test
to handle mouse events. This cures the deadlock, because it's
always safe to post a command. The same is already done for
remote control events. In a real xlet, mouse events don't
need to be queued like this - it's OK to just stall the mouse
thread (if it exists) until the show is in a state where the
model can be updated.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-103] Better support for game animations (Feature.clone(), others?)
item.description: There's a need for
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Better support for game animations (Feature.clone(), others?)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
There's a need for better support for game animations in the GRIN show graph.

One thing that games do is they'll have a visual element – often an image, it might however be a small scene graph tree, with
maybe a translation, an image or two, an image sequence, or perhaps an assembly (to support a "ship blows up" sequence, for
example). Often, you want to clone a visual element to make a new one (e.g. making a new enemy spaceship to fight, or
whatever). This can be added to the GRIN scene graph pretty easily, I think:

o Add the method Feature.clone(). To simplify implementation, it should only be called on
a prepared feature (and throw IllegalStateException otherwise), and it should be in the contract
that it's allowed to throw NotImplementedException. All of the GRIN features should implement it,
but user extensions might not.

o I guess that commands inside a cloned segment that refer to a feature being cloned need to be
moved over to the cloned version of the feature, so you can do things like reset the assembly after
the "enemy blows up" animation, for example.

o Add a "games" library alongside GRIN with a Group feature that's made to have nodes added and removed
dynamically.

It might make sense to also add some kind of collision detection support, at least for a game that's currently
being written. This probably wouldn't be a feature; it's be more of a object that refers to a feature, maybe.
Or, maybe collision detection belongs outside of the library, and should just be done in program logic... Not
sure about this one.

A good exercise would be to re-code Gun Bunny to use the GRIN scene graph, extended along the lines described
above.

Feature.cloneSubgraph() so that a game can take a subtree of
the scene graph, and create multiple copies. Modified Group
so that you can dynamically add and remove cloned features from
a group's visible set. Re-wrote the Gun Bunny game as GrinBunny,
a game that's nearly functionally identical, but that uses the
GRIN scene graph for display, state management, resource management,
and remote control management.

      • BACKWARDS COMPATIBILTY WARNING - SEE NEXT ISSUE ****

(no issue #) Fixed timer. Timer was always running one frame too long,
which meant that the fastest repeating timer would fire every two frames.
This putback fixes that, which also means that all timers will run correctly
now, which is one frame faster than they used to. There's an outside
chance that this might cause off-by-one-frame bugs in some existing
shows.

(no issue #) Added a "-director" argument to GrinView. This lets you
extend GrinView with your own director. This is nice for shows where
the BD-dependent functionality can be segregated outside of the director,
because it means you can more easily execute the application inside

logic inside the director, which lets you debug and play the game within

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-102] Sticky Images
item.description:
For GRIN 1.0, it's highly desirable to have "sticky" images. A sticky image is one that stays in memory
once loaded. So, for example, a show would be structured to load it normally (by having a segment that
prepares the image before it's used), but if the control flow goes through that path a second time, the
image loading would happen instantly.

This can be accomplished by modifying ManagedImage to do a ref-counting of "stickyness". That way,
any code can make any image sticky (and undo its action), without needing to coordinate with other code
that might use the same image. Then, Show can maintain a list of images that the give show wants to be
sticky throughout the show's lifetime.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Sticky Images

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
This adds support to ManagedImage for "sticky images". If you
want an image to stay in memory once loaded, set it to sticky
(by calling ManagedImage.makeSticky()). Each call to makeSticky()
must eventually be balanced with a call to unmakeSticky().

Took advantage of the sticky image support in Show, by having a list
of images that are to be sticky. They're made sticky when the show is
initialized, and "unmade" sticky when the show is destroyed.

Changed GrinView so that it destroys the show before calling
System.exit(0). This way, I was able to check that unmakeSticky()
works (by running GrinView on menu.txt, navigating to S:Initialize
then S:NullSegment, then exiting GrinView).

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-101] m2ts transcoder would be nice
item.description:
It would be great if we could injest a video file with a more standard encapsulation, like .mov or .mp4,
and spit out a .m2ts file (an MPEG-2 transport stream). Maybe such a program could also do a bit of
parsing of the contents (H.264, VC-1 or MPEG-2) and verify that it was encoded in a way that obeys
the BD constraints.

Without this, you can always make a disc image by buying something like DVD-IT Pro, but what you can't
do is ingest video as a web service, transcode it to m2ts, then make it available for peoples' discs for a VFS
update.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: m2ts transcoder would be nice

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
This would take a fair amount of R&D to pull off (mostly R, I think). The hard part is that one would
have to tear apart the ingest format (.mov or .mp4 or .wmv, presumably), and extract stuff like the time
relationships between the different streams. Much of that info doesn't go into the .m2ts file; it ends up
in the playlist file, in places like the StreamAttribute of the stream table. See DiscCreationTools/playlist
for an XML representation of the needed playlist data.

There's a big question of how far one would want to go. At one extreme is a full disc authoring tool,
with multiple streams of audio, video, subtitles and triggers. At another extreme is a simple tool that
takes a .mp4 file with one audio track and one video track, and makes a playlist/m2ts to play it.

In the middle there might be a sweet spot, e.g. a tool that lets you insert triggers, and layer a single SD
A/V stream into an already-existing playlist that has a primary HD video stream (and subtitles and
triggers and all that good stuff). This would let you do the effect of ingesting video from the viewer's
camcorder, and integrating it into the movie experience (e.g. by having a movie character sit down to
watch your home movie).

Once that's done, it might turn out to be not so hard to allow an XML description of the full structure to
drive creation of the playlist/m2ts file. Maybe.

Caveat: When this discussion was added, we hadn't looked deeply into the relevant specifications. This
analysis is mostly based on informal conversations with some who are skilled in the art.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-100] Optimize start-up time by combining classes
item.description:
Measurements indicate that classloading may be moderately expensive on the slower players. The figures
aren't quite in yet, but it does appear worthwhile to try to minimize the number of classes in GRIN, as long
as it doesn't compromise the model the developer sees. As a secondary concern, it shouldn't compromise
the internal structure too much.

Some examples of this already having been done are how the implementation of the segment_done and
sync_display commands are collapsed into GrinXHelper at runtime, and how timer, scaling_model and
translation_model are collapsed into InterpolatedModel. For GRIN 1.0, a pass should be taken through the
implementation looking for other economies in the number of classes.

Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Optimize start-up time by combining classes

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-99] Canonicalize more stuff in the Grin binary writer
item.description:
Some (or maybe all?) of the GRIN command types can be canonicalized. For example, take the
segment_done command. Since it's stateless, there's no real reason to have more than one instance
representing a segment_done command in memory for a given show. Generally speaking, at least the
built-in commands can be canonicalized in the GRIN binary writer, resulting in smaller show files and less
RAM footprint. It's worth poking around to see if there are other objects that could be profitably
canonicalzed, as part of optimizations going into GRIN 1.0.

Platform: Macintosh

comments.comment:
r420 (see issue 137 for webrev attachment):

This is a moderately complex putback. It is completely
backwards-compatible with exist projects, but it includes
changes to the .grin binary file format, a significant
new feature ("named commands"), and a structural change to
how remote control keypresses are handled.

Issue 137, "Named GRIN commands"

Added named commands in shows, via these public interfaces:

Show.getNamedCommand(String) to look one up
named_command in show file to create one
run_named_command in show file to run one

This provides a facility to declare a command (or a list of commands), and
give it a name. This can be used to declare a set of commands in the show
file, where it's natural to do so, and then use them on a show (via
Show.runCommand(Command)) from Java code, which can be in any thread.
This can also be handy when there are multiple shows, since Java code
in the director can be under the control of one show, but queue commands
to another.

Issue 141, "Remote control handling improvements (commands)"

Made Show so that it only takes out a local lock when it processes
remote control key press and release events. These events are now
queued like commands, and executed in the animation loop.

Issue 99, "Canonicalize more stuff in the GRIN binary writer"

Now, command instances and command arrays are canonicalized.
Extension commands need to override equals(Object) and hashCode()
if they want to be canonicalized, of course.

The GRIN binary file size remains about the same, but the runtime
memory footprint should go down, particularly since simple, command
command arrays are shared. This is particularly true if there are
many empty command arrays, or command arrays that only contain a
single command like segment_done.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-97] Need sync_display command
item.description:
There are occasions when you need to wait until the screen has caught up with the program before doing
something. For example, on some players, working with JMF can be a time-consuming operation that can
take hundreds or thousands of miliseconds. During this time, the screen might not update, so it's a good
idea to e.g. make sure the screen has actually cleared before launching a command that uses JMF, e.g. to
select a playlist.

The command system has this built in already via deferPendingCommands(), but a standardized
sync_display command was never added to the GRIN command set.

item.summary: Need sync_display command

comments.comment:
r341:
Fix for issue 97, "Need sync_display command".
Also, creation of classload time measurement xlet that can be
adapted to do other interesting statistical performance measurements.

The old way of doing sync_display was to make a command that returned
true from deferPendingCommands(). This is pretty counter-intuitive; it's
more natural to just have a sync_display command, rather than building a
flag into every command object. This putback corrects this design

The implementation of sync_display and segment_done have been

minimize the number of classes at runtime, in order to have the
lowest possible startup time.

Added a new benchmark application to test classloading time on
a variety of players. Perliminary results suggest that collapsing
classes is justified, at least where it doesn't compromise the
design too much.

While looking at this, I realized that there was a call to

set up. This was correct when written, but it's a fragile and
unnecessary thing to do. It's also broken now, because there's
a small but finite chance that it might cause the state of the

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-96] Add and remove animation clients
item.description:
We need an ability to add and remove animation clients from a running animation engine. The current
model of creating a new engine requires deallocating then reallocating the graphics buffer used for
double-buffering, which could cause fragmentation of image space. Also, it means destroying a thread
and creating a new one.

I think the right two methods to add are:

resetAnimationClients(AnimationClient[])

Sets the animation clients to the new set. The current frame of animation will run to completion before
anything is changed. Once that's done, any clients not present in the new set will be destroyed, and
any new clients will be initialized. This destroy/initialize work will be done in the animation thread;
this method returns immediately, without waiting for the clients to actually be set.

AnimationClient[] getAnimationClients()

returns a copy of the current set of animation clients. This always returns what was set last, whether or
not those are the clients being animated.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Add and remove animation clients

part here is re-initializing the drawing optimization information
in RenderContext. That information is kept in a fairly non-OO way
(using an old-style doubly linked list) in order to get runtime
efficiency and prevent garbage generation during animation. That's
a good result, but it does mean that this kind of change requires
a close look.

Added a new "Playground" functional test xlet to test features like
this that don't fit naturally into the cookbook menu xlet.

Made colors more space-efficient in the binary file by writing
the RGBA value as a single int, instead of four.

on the Rictor scale.

item.summary: Support needed for font strips

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Some notes from conversation with Bill.

  • Font strip is a collection of images representing characters. Render each
    character as a image, and not resulting strings that's needed by BD-J app.
  • Load font dynamically on jdk instead of requiring OS install, render chars in
    size that's needed by the BD-J app since scaling will make it look bad, and then
    store them as images. Also store various FontMatrics information to some file
    at that moment too.
  • At runtime, kerning needs to happen. We can render every character pairs on
    jdk and find out kerning for them, and store that info to be used at runtime too.
  • It's quite common for a designer to add visual enhancement to a given font
    set, such as adding a drop shadow. The tool needs to support this workflow,
    hence the tool should be in twofolds - the first step is to read in JDK font and
    render a image with different visual aids so that fonts can be modified using
    Photoshop or other tools; and the second step is to read in this possibly
    modified intermediate rendered image and produce a final image that xlet will
    use on the disc.
  • The visual aid should include the maximum bounding box between each characters
    that the designer can play with, and the absolute location of the actual
    characters; this part requires some cross-checks.
  • On a second run of the tool, it should read in the possibly modified image,
    and compare the pixel data with an already saved font metrics info to find out
    what the "padding" or decoration pixels are. The final image should include no
    more pixels than what's needed.
  • Kerning on a drop-shadow doesn't need to be padded per each char, but just
    around the whole string.
  • The tool should take a configuration file as an argument. This config file
    will at least contain
    All the characters that need to be included in the font strip,
    Font's color to be rendered,
    Background color of the font image,
    Each char's bounding box size,
    Color of the visual aid (guideline)s in the metrics
    ... etc.
  • This will be GRIN's extension feature, maybe as a subclass of the Text feature.

Committed FontStrip extension feature, a font image generation tool, and some
samples to the trunk at r388. Commit message below.

===========================
Adding FontStrip extension feature and a font image generation tool under
AuthoringTools/grin/extensions/fontstrip. These let GRIN show use
set of image files containing pre-rendered characters for displaying
text, therefore omitting the need to bundle BD-J content with openfont files.

Please take a look at the README.txt file under the fontstrip directory to
ee how to generate font image, BNF syntax for the extension, where to find
examples using the feature, etc.
===========================

comments.comment:
Two performance hint to add:

With mosaics, it's a bit faster to have one setup clause with one image from
each mosaic, then go on to setting up all features. This short-circuits some thread
context switches.

Also, if all parts of an assembly have some features that are the same, it's more efficient
to hoist them out of the assembly.

I think the document that's needed here is a description of the scene graph, and the scene graph
compiler. Notably, it needs to mention compilation options, like image matrixes, and the new feature
of scaling a scene graph.

Here's a quick outline:

Visual features
fixed_image (show w/o setup and w/ setup)
image_sequence
text, others
Structural features
group (and how the same image can't appear twice)
assembly (flesh out double use checker)
menu_assembly
segments
rc_handlers
scripting
director model
the compiler
image matrixes
scaling
java_command and GrinXHellper

There should also be a section on GRIN extensions, and extension parsers. This might also mention
GrinXML.

Modifier features belongs between visual features and structural features.

Linking image_sequence nodes needs to be described, as does the InterpolatedModel separation.

A leitmotif of this documentation is when various things can be done (i.e. the state model of various
bits of the system). Setup maybe deserves its own section, perhaps even at the beginning. Definitley,
the threading model needs to be described – maybe WeatherWidget is a good example to structure
that around, describing the animation thread, the setup thread and the networking thread.

Make sure sticky images get discussed somewhere.

On src_over and fade, the nature of java.awt.Graphics' dueling AlphaComposite should be mentioned.

For the visual RC handler, the interaction with assembly is the key point to get across.

A state/timeline/interaction diagram would be a good way to describe the threading... See Jaya's j1-hdc-
lightening.pdf on dropbox.

mostly addressed by r525, but leaving state as "STARTED" because this writeup still needs to be proofread.

r525:
Significantly expanded the page at
https://hdcookbook.dev.java.net/grin.html to include a
fairly complete tour of the GRIN scene graph and the GRIN
compiler.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-89] GrinView should support multiple shows
item.description:
It should be possible to invoke GrinView with multiple show files.

I guess this would cause the different shows to be stacked atop eachother, by setting up the animator
with multiple draw targets (presumably in the order on the command line). Each show would have its
own selector window, so you can "pilot" the simulation with any combination of segments displaying
simultaneously.

This would be useful for testing overlapping shows, which is something the framework supports, and
which might be useful for things like the functional equivalent of a pop-up menu. The animation
framework was designed specifically to support overlapping shows; it even supports named draw
targets, so that drawing optimization can be coordinated among the overlapping shows.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-85] Add a generic VFSUpdate reverting to Bridgehead
item.description:
This is related to issue 75.

It is getting clear that once a VFSUpdate happens successfully, the updated disc
image is expected to stay even after the disc is ejected from the player.

This leads to a need for bridgehead to provide a reliable way to call API for
reverting back the VFSUpdate, even in a case that the updated disc image's xlet
crashes.

For this, we have to make bridgehead not replace the entire BDMV directory
structure. At minimum, there has to be error or some warning if index.bdmv is
going to be overwritten.

I was first thinking about having a title unbound xlet to be around in the
updated disc image structure, but after talking with Bill and studying
index.bdmv structure, I'm starting to think that using firstplayback title for
reverting xlet could do. I can make the reverting xlet have some bdjo number
that is unlikely to conflict with usual case (like 90000) and make that as a
firstplaylist, while topmenu can start back a standard bdjo, say, 00000,
possibly through HDMV. I'm told that firstplaylist in hollywood titles are
typically a FBI warning, so hopefully there won't be issue with using that for
bridgehead during development.
item.summary: Add a generic VFSUpdate reverting to Bridgehead

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Fix committed at r314 and 315.

Changing the bridgehead disc structure so that the bridgehead xlet is launched
as a first playlist instead of the first title in the titles array. The topmenu
still launches the first title (00000), and this is expected to be overwritten
by the bridgehead user. The bridgehead xlet offers a menu option to revert
back the VFS update and go back to the optical disc structure.

Also added a check in the disc image download section, to make sure that the new
disc image will not overwrite bridgehead xlet's bdjo/jar, or the first playlist
of the index.bdmv to be other than bridgehead. The VFS update is not going to
happen if the error is detected.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-84] OrgID should not be made mandatory for certificate generation
item.description:
Customer says:
We are putting an OrgID in the root cert of all zeros (00000000) since BDSigner
always requires an OrgID. You might want to change the cert generation function
to leave off the OrgID field if it is a root cert or bu cert. That would make
this more clear to users.

Our response:

It makes sense for the BDCertGenerator not to mandate OrgID argument when
the root certificate is being requested, and make it an optional argument instead.

However, it's nice to mandate it when an application leaf certificate is being
generated. If the application cert is being generated and an OrgID is not
specified a WARNING message can be issued. It may not be an error case as all
the application certs need not be leaf certs. (Practically, for cert chain
length of 2 they are..)

For Binding Unit Certificate, however, OrgID is required in the certificate.
It's used by some of the players (like Arcsoft TMT) to match with the orgID in
the BUMF file (However PS3 does not check for this property). It's better to be
conservative here so that applications do not fail on some of the players. The
orgID is made mandatory for the binding unit certificate.
item.summary: OrgID should not be made mandatory for certificate generation

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-75] VFS "bridgehead" disc is desirable
item.description:
With BD-Live, it's no longer necessary to burn a disc in order to do development. Instead, a small fixed
xlet can download a disc image over your LAN (using ftp or whatever you like) from your development
workspace, and copy it to the BUDA. Then, it can do a VFS update and re-launch the title. Voil!
You're now running your development workspace.

Now that we have VFS working, we should make ourselves one of these.

Maybe we could have an option to leave the VFS updater running title unbound, as configured by (say) a
file in the development workspace. That way, the VFS updater "executive" xlet could, when (say) the
red button is pressed, grab a new disc image and re-launch, without needing to eject/reinsert the disc.
Or, maybe this is overkill.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: VFS "bridgehead" disc is desirable

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
About the network protocol, ftp is probably way overkill. I think a good way to go would be for the
bridgehead xlet to display the player's IP address on the screen, then set up a ServerSocket on some
convenient port (like 6000). Then, on the development machine (where you have a keyboard you
can use to enter the player's IP address), a Swing app can connect to that ServerSocket, and send
something really simple, like:

  • A byte[] containing a .zip file with the new file contents to overlay on the existing
    disc image. The xlet could use, say, ZipInputStream to unpack this and copy it to the BUDA
  • A list of strings containing files to be deleted

Note that for BUDA access, the private signature used to create the original disc needs to be
maintained in the development workspace, so that the VFS update will work. Thanks, Chihiro,
for pointing this out.

Basing on the VFSTest structure. It's turning out to be:

  • BridgeheadXlet (bootstrapped on the disc and waits for the connection request)
  • ClientFrame (The one that connects to the Bridgehead, with an optional GUI front)
  • A sample directory that creates a disc image and the bumf.* files that the
    BridgeheadXlet can upload.

Fixed in r297. No webrev, all new files under trunk/tools/bridgehead.

One enhancement that'll help is to establish a way to revert back to the
bridgehead xlet after an update so that a more disc image can be loaded.
However, by doing an update, the bridgehead is gone, and it's in a mercy of the
test disc image to take some signal and call VFSUpdate method with null
parameters to get back to the bridgehead, as far as I can tell. Need to
investigate further. Right now, PS/3 automatically reverts back by restarting
the disc playback (v2.35).

Note that the VFS update reverting part has been handled under a separate issue,
#85.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-74] BDSigner: A new default key alias is needed for the Binding Unit Cert
item.description:
The application root certificate and the binding unit root certificate share the
same default alias 'rootcert'.

If a binding unit root cert is created after a application root cert using
default aliases (hard-coded in the SecurityUtil class), or vise-versa, one of
them will overwrite the other as they both share the same alias. This problem is
exposed in a confusing way only at the time when these certs are used for signing.

Note that the binding unit root cert has a capability to sign any content while
the root certificate can only sign another certificate. Hence signing can go bad
either way.
item.summary: BDSigner: A new default key alias is needed for the Binding Unit Cert

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-73] Logger can do automatically display log messages
item.description:
The Logger starts displaying the log messages only when the REFRESH button (3)
at the bottom of the logging screen is pressed. One won't start seeing the
messages until then.

This coupled with some delay for the logger to start displaying messages, leaves
the users wondering if the Xlet is indeed behaving the way it is expected to.

It would be useful to have the logger to start displaying the messages without
having to wait for the user input, this also helps to a certain extent in
associating the time line when the message is getting logged to what's taking
place on the screen.
item.summary: Logger can do automatically display log messages

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Agreed that the logger can be improved to suit our need better.
This library is ported from the test disc team, and for them, the display need
is secondary compared to the need of saving info to the file for the later
inspection. Hence, currently, the logger writes all the Logger.log(Str) input
to a file right away, and the display reads the info from the file - and this
file reload only happens when pressing "3".

Another issue is that for our use, there's a much greater chance of an file I/O
failure (error in configuration, signing, etc) and we still want some info to be
displayed on the screen.

Committed at r274. Adding a new class XletLogger.java, which is a wrapper class
that works with the underlying classes from the test disc team. Like the Logger

  • The log goes to System.out and to the XletLoggerDialog automatically, and

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-71] frame length, size ralated bug in soundgen tool
item.description:
soundgen tool converts a set of audio input files into a sound.bdmv file. But
when input files are not 48KHZ, 16 bit samples (as required by sound.bdmv spec),

item.description:

We're using GrinXML but have a little utility that Richard wrote which will take a folder of images and
make a dummy GRIN show file to feed to the mosaic maker.

We've got a couple images that use full screen height and the mosaic maker doesn't like that. Without a
hint it complains they're too big and it errors out. Images can be larger than 1080 pixels high in BD-J,
though, so I'm not sure why it's a problem?

So then I added a hint to do the two full height images in their own mosaic. This gets further, and
mosaic maker makes the mosaics, but errors out when it's saving the file:

[java] 2 mosaics created.
[java] Wrote 04501\assets\im0.png
[java] Exception in thread "main" java.awt.image.RasterFormatException: negative or zero width
[java] at java.awt.image.Raster.<init>(Unknown Source)

[java] at sun.awt.image.SunWritableRaster.<init>(Unknown Source)

[java] at sun.awt.image.IntegerInterleavedRaster.<init>(Unknown Source)
[java] at sun.awt.image.IntegerInterleavedRaster.createWritableChild(Unknown Source)
[java] at java.awt.image.BufferedImage.getSubimage(Unknown Source)
[java] at com.hdcookbook.grin.mosaic.Mosaic.writeBuffer(Mosaic.java:212)
[java] at com.hdcookbook.grin.mosaic.MosaicMaker.makeMosaics(MosaicMaker.java:290)
[java] at com.hdcookbook.grin.build.mosaic.Main.main(Main.java:148)

If you have a chance, would you mind reviewing?

adding algorithms), too.

see the result has a big yellow hole at the bottom right. The Images could've been moved around to

comments.comment:
This probably subsumes issue 33, which is about using mosaic builder without a GRIN show.

The exception turns out to be pretty simple, and related to a bad show file. When a show has a
mosaic_hint for a mosaic, but none of the images in that mosaic are used in the show, then it would
trigger this bug. The fix to that part is to issue warnings when images aren't used, and to discard empty
mosaics.

Better optimizing a mosaic is NP-complete, but there are good pruning algorithms. They require more
parameters (like min/max width, number of iterations to keep trying to optimize a solution, etc.). This
feels like it should be put in the show file, and not as command-line arguments.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-61] Programmatic control of show nodes
item.description:
There's a need for xlet code to be able to control some of the parameters of show nodes, in order to
achieve arbitrary animation. For example:

  • Code should be able to change a translation in order to effect
    up/down/right/left movements
  • Code should be able to compute arbitrary algorithmic values for nodes

This has to be integrated into the threading model. I think this has two parts: An xlet should be able
to get a callback once per frame from a show, and an xlet should be able to post a command to change
at least some of the values of at least some node types.

The callback should probably come after all of the commands for a frame have been processed, so that
the model is up to date. If the callback posts more commands, they should probably be processed
immediately, in the current frame. The callback should probably come on a ShowListener that gets
created out of issue 14 (Limited support for GRIN events).

The command to change a node values might be as simple as a command that changes the parameters
of an InterpolatedModel that has no values in its "int[][] values" data member. That gets us
programmatic control of translation and scale. It's not clear if we want programmatic control of the
image within an image sequence, the color of text or a box, or the alpha value of a fade node, but
these can be considered. One nice thing about changing the values of an InterpolatedModel is we'd
only need one command class, which helps to keep the size of our runtime library down.

The solution for this should work for Java code in an xlet, and should also elegantly transfer to a
system using FX/Script at runtime.

This issue was originally split out from issue 12.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Programmatic control of show nodes

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Assigning to myself after speaking with Bill.

Need to go through the existing nodes to see hwat might make sense to allow
runtime change, but the obvious candidates seems to be the text value for Text,
color for Box, and InterpolatedModel, which covers timer, translation and
scaling. Discussed that having one NodeUpdateCommand class that takes Object,
and then make Nodes that can be controlled at runtime to have
set(NodeUpdateCommand) method that internally posts this command to a pending
command queue. That way, we can be reusing the same command definitions across
multiple Nodes.
See issue 14 about ShowListener interface.

I think the best way to do this is mostly documentation, with a bit of an extension of how commands
work.

It's easy enough to make a method that sets the values of e.g. an InterpolatedModel; the hard part is
updating that value at the right time. A good way to do that is to make up a command. A really
efficient way to do this would be a java_command that pulls the values from an xlet class (e.g. the
director), and stuffs them into the show nodes. Of course, an xlet Command subclass works fine too,
and is maybe a bit more elegant, but it leads to a lot of small command classes.

Two elements are needed to bring this about elegantly:

1) An xlet needs to have a way of getting an instance of the java_command that gets declared in the
show file. This could be done as a named static factory method of the class that implements
java_command. (Another alternative would be to make a timer that repeatedly fires the java_command,
but that doesn't elegantly allow for event-driven commands, e.g. from keypresses).

2) There needs to be documentation about which node-altering methods can be called in this way, and
they should have assertions that make it illegal to use them in a thread-unsafe way. I think this means
asserting that the methods are only called from within the animation thread.

revision 354:

Issue 14, "Limited support for Grin Events"

Added methods to Director that an xlet can override if it wishes to
be informed of each new animation frame, of new segments being
selected, or of new assembly parts being selected.

=========================

Issue 61, "Programmatic control of show events"

Added a couple of methods on InterpolatedModel and Fade so
that those parameters can be modified from code. Wrote a fair
amount of documentation about when it's OK to call these methods.
Created an example in Playground of Java code that uses the random
number generator to randomly mess with all the Feature parameters
that can be changed from within Java.

As detailed GRIN's main documentation page, there are a fair number
of show nodes that can be modified from code. See grin/doc-files/index.html
under the "Programmatically Controlling Show Nodes" major heading for
details.

=========================

(no issue #) Harmless race condition

Fixed a race condition with remote control input events. This
race condition would be incredibly unlikely to occur in practice,
especially where there's only one GRIN show being animated, because
the remote control input thread would have to pre-empt the animation
thread between the time addDisplayAreas() completes and when paintFrame()
starts, which is a very short time. Even if that did happen, the way
the drawing optimization works would have prevented any incorrect
display from lasting more than a frame. With
all this said, now mouse and remote control input is deferred until it's
unquestionably safe to process it.

=========================

(no issue #) Got rid of an unneeded internal inner class of Command.

=========================

(no issue #) Relative translators had gotten broken in the text file format;
this was fixed.

=========================

(no issue #) Set up library dependencies in NetBeans so that "find usages"
would work. Unfortunately, to get it to work I had to point to a
source version of the BD-J stubs, using an absolute pathname, but maybe
if others want to do "find usages" they might figure out that a global
search-and-replace in various NB xml files will set that up. I don't
know how to do the moral equivalent of user.vars.properties for a
NB project, alas.

=========================

Reviewed by Sundar, Chihiro

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-56] Automatic image slicing for menus
item.description:
Imagine that you have a big graphic with a background that includes a set of buttons in the normal
state, and a set of much smaller images for the buttons only in the selected and activated states.
Currently, you have two choices:

1) Slice the big image up into smaller sub-images so you can display everything except the
button "cut-outs", and then build a menu_assembly to put everything back together again

2) Just display the big background image and paint the other states on top of it, even though
this involves more drawing at runtime.

If the button "cut-outs" aren't tiny, #1 is probably more efficient at runtime, but it's a lot of manual
work right now. Slicing up images is something that could be done at compile time automatically.

Thanks to Phil for asking the question that lead to this realization!

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-52] Start doing tagging and promotion for hdcookbook
item.description:
There has been a request that with active development going into the hdcookbook
code base, it would be useful to tag specific "releases" and identify more or
less the stable revision numbers of the repository. Apparently it's been quite
difficult to track changes and keep things stable for those who are extending
our Grin codebase.
item.summary: Start doing tagging and promotion for hdcookbook

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Started on the technical changes, such as adding some autotest capability and an
build option to make a promotion bundle. Still need to figure out logistics,
such as what/where/how to put up on the hdcookbook web site etc.

To see changes happened in the repository, please see the webrev attached to the
issue 53.

We've started doing daily builds using Hudson on an internal server, in which
some auto tests are executed with GrinView. When a major enhancement or fix has
gone into the trunk, it gets tagged, and the build from it gets uploaded to the
"Documents and Files" section of the hdcookbook.dev.java.net, and the changelog
gets appended.

Making this issue as fixed, since I've finally put in a link to the hdcookbook
top page for downloading binaries.

Currently the process of gathering update info, tagging a revision and uploading
corresponding build to the open source area is all manual. It will be nice to
automate some of this moving forward.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-51] Add capability for multiple signers to sign jarfiles to the BDSigner tool
item.description:
The BDSigner currently can be used to sign by a single signer. It would be nice
to extend it for multiple signers to sign the jar.

The current implementation always uses SIG-BD-00.* as the signature filename,
hence overwriting the signature files with the signature of the recent most
signer. We should either let the users choose the signature filenames or
generate it ourselves depending on the number of signers of the jar file.
item.summary: Add capability for multiple signers to sign jarfiles to the BDSigner tool

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-50] GrinBinaryReader should use AssetFinder for Font creation
item.description:
Below is a report of the issue;
----------------------
I think there is a problem with how the binary reader in Grin handles fonts.
Right now (at least the last revision I pulled down), after reading the font
information from the file, it instantiates the font using the java.awt.Font
constructor. In BD-J, however, this has to go through the DVB
FontFactory.createFont() API.

I believe Bill had addressed this in earlier versions of Grin by defining a Font
"helper" as a part of AssetFinder. There was a method on the AssetFinder class
that would use a registered "helper" to generate an instance of the font you
request. In this way, the desktop environment and Xlet environments could have
their own methods for creating a font.
----------------------

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-49] GrinView with null-name Segment, selecting assembly parts
item.description:
Apparently GrinView doesn't let the user select Segments whose name is null;
nothing happens for double-clicking the segment tree node in this case.
item.summary: GrinView with null-name Segment, selecting assembly parts

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
In addition to the above, it would be nice if you could click on an assembly part, and have that part
become the one that's activated within the assembly.

r370:

Issue 103: "Better support for game animations." Implemented
Feature.cloneSubgraph() so that a game can take a subtree of
the scene graph, and create multiple copies. Modified Group
so that you can dynamically add and remove cloned features from
a group's visible set. Re-wrote the Gun Bunny game as GrinBunny,
a game that's nearly functionally identical, but that uses the
GRIN scene graph for display, state management, resource management,
and remote control management.

      • BACKWARDS COMPATIBILTY WARNING - SEE NEXT ISSUE ****

(no issue #) Fixed timer. Timer was always running one frame too long,
which meant that the fastest repeating timer would fire every two frames.
This putback fixes that, which also means that all timers will run correctly
now, which is one frame faster than they used to. There's an outside
chance that this might cause off-by-one-frame bugs in some existing
shows.

(no issue #) Added a "-director" argument to GrinView. This lets you
extend GrinView with your own director. This is nice for shows where
the BD-dependent functionality can be segregated outside of the director,
because it means you can more easily execute the application inside
GrinView, on desktop JDK. For example, GrinBunny puts all of the game
logic inside the director, which lets you debug and play the game within
GrinView.

(no issue #) Fixed "grinview -scale" - it used to generate a null
pointer exception under certain circumstances.

(no issue #) Made "linear-relative" translation preferred, and deprecated
"linear". Made it a parse error if a show mixes the two, rather than just
ignoring all but the last one. Added documentation
to the show BNF explaining why non-relative positioning was a bad idea.

(no issue #) Changed the method InterpolatedModel.getCurrValue(int) to
getField(int), for symmetry with setField(int, int). This is a change
to the public API, but in a fairly new method that has an obvious
mapping, so if anyone has javac blow up on them, it shouldn't take
long to find!

Issue 49: "Grinview with null-name segment, selecting assembly parts."
Now you can double-click on an unnamed segment and have it work. Also,
if you double-click on an assembly part, instead of doing an
activate_segment, it will do an activate_part on the assembly. This
is really handy for debugging the contents of assemblies.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-48] Menu Build doesn't work on OS/X - jarsigner, perhaps?
item.description:
When building using JDK 1.6 from developer.apple.com, the build runs without error, but the resulting
disc image doesn't work on any tested player. We suspect this is because the jarsigner tool is overriding
platform classes, and for whatever reason this override isn't happening on the standard OS/X Java
installation.

The current plan is to re-write the jarsigner so that it doesn't override JDK internals.
item.environment:
Operating System: Mac OS X
Platform: Macintosh
item.summary: Menu Build doesn't work on OS/X - jarsigner, perhaps?

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
The BDSigner (jarsigner) has now been modified not to override the JDK
jarsigner. This removes the direct dependency on the jarsigner.

However, BDSigner makes use of the following Sun internal APIs:

import sun.security.tools.KeyTool;
import sun.security.tools.JarSigner;
import sun.security.util.DerInputStream;
import sun.security.util.DerOutputStream;
import sun.security.pkcs.ContentInfo;
import sun.security.pkcs.PKCS7;
import sun.security.pkcs.SignerInfo;
import sun.misc.BASE64Decoder;
import sun.tools.jar.Main;

There are already bugs against JDK to make these APIs publicly accessible as
many Java developers use them. They've been filed years ago (4 -7 years).
As many people rely on them, we hope these (internal) APIs are unlikely to be
changed in incompatible ways.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-46] Grinview and different screen sizes
item.description:
Grinview should have a command-line option to specify the normal screen sizes, plus arbitrary sizes.
Nice names for the standard sizes might be "1080", "720", "qhd", "ntsc", "pal" and "secam". ("hd" could be
an alias for 1080, maybe, but personally I don't like the inference that 720p60 isn't HD).
item.summary: Grinview and different screen sizes

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Assigning to myself. GenericMain.adjustScreenSize(int scale) probably can be
expanded to handle these options as well.

Adding input from Mark Johnson on this topic too, as a point of reference.
--------------------------------------
As a final note, the GrinView currently always assumes a screen size of
1920x1080. In practice, however, multiple different screen sizes may be
commonly used. For instance, most BD discs today incorporate a fair
amount of SD content at 720x480 (NTSC) or 720x576 (PAL). While less
common, 1440x1080 and 1280x720 resolutions may also be used in
some cases. In our old customized version of the viewer, we allowed
screen size to be specified on the command line, and it proved quite
helpful on current projects for handling SD resolutions.
--------------------------------------

Committed r252. GrinView now takes -screensize <keyword> arguments. Possible
keywords are:

720x480, 480, 480i, 480p, ntsc
720x576, 576, 576i, 576p, pal, secam
1280x720, 720, 720p
960x540, 960, qhd
1440x1080, 1440
1920x1080, 1080, 1080p, 1080i, fullhd

The default is 1920x1080, with a scaling factor 2.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-43] hdcookbook build error with a keytool error message
item.description:
When one tries do an incremental build (not cleanup and build) with the
hdcookbook project in netbeans an error with the message:

sign-xlets:
[java] keytool error: java.lang.Exception: Alias <appcert> does not exist

This keystore cleanup process needs to address this issue.
item.summary: hdcookbook build error with a keytool error message

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
The cleanup process tries to delete the keystore file, but sometimes the windows
file system does not delete it (for there are still some references to the file).
Hence an empty keystore file is left behind.
When a new keystore is being created, the existing keys (aliases) are deleted.
The cleanup process can just check for existing aliases in the keystore and then
try deleting them.
Tested with hdcookbook incremental build. The issue is not seen anymore.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-42] Add certificate related options to BDCertGenerator tool
item.description:
Below is the original request:

BDCertGenerator.java needs to be modified to support specifying all cert fields
on the command line instead of them being hard-coded. It would need its own
main() function also. The usage would be (ignoring the full classpath):

BDCertGenerator -keystore STORE N ORGID EMAIL L S C

  • STORE = keystore where cert and keypair will be saved after generation
  • N = The name of the company the keys are for. It is used in the CommonName
    field and concatenated with the ORGID for the OrganizationName field
  • ORGID = hex organization ID (32-bit)
  • EMAIL = email address of contact for this company
  • L = LocalityName (city)
  • S = StateOrProvince Name
  • C = CountryName

We are ok with these fields remaining hard-coded:

  • OrganizationalUnitName: we just put "Blu-ray" since it's redundant
  • ExpirationDate: this is the same for all certs and is essentially unlimited
  • IssuerAltName and SubjectAltName: these could just be filled in with the email
    address from the EMAIL value specified on the command line
  • KeyUsage and BasicConstraints: hard-coded as now

The certificate and private key would be stored in the specified keystore file.
If the "-keystore" argument is not present, you could default to "keystore.store".

Example usage:
BDCertGenerator -keystore fox.store "Fox Studios" AA1234BB production@fox.com
"San Francisco" "CA" "US"
item.summary: Add certificate related options to BDCertGenerator tool

Note: The organization_id is appended to the org name
component of both names

-debug :Prints debug messages

In the absense of this option, a default
store:"keystore.store"
is used from the current working directory.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-39] Better way to resolve forward referencing for show nodes
item.description:
A follow-up for issue #37.

Currently there is no good way for the custom features to resolve references,
which might haven't yet set up by then. Need to update the binary file building
process so that forward references will not be an issue, possibly by breaking
the process in two-folds (first pass to create all the objects and the second
pass to populate data in them).
item.summary: Better way to resolve forward referencing for show nodes

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Added various setter methods to grin nodes. Still need to add base constructors
and then change binary converter to create instances through them.
Changing the owner.
Started.

Upcoming changes include the followings:

  • Introducing SE mirror versions of the Show nodes, such as SEAssembly,
    SECommandRCHandler, etc. This is only for the concrete classes existing in the
    library side. There is no SEFeature or SECommand.
  • Node and SENode interfaces are defined, which defines readInstance() and
    writeInstance() methods respectively. All library side Show nodes implement
    Node, all SE side nodes implement SENode.
  • Each node takes care of writing itself out and reading itself in from the
    binary file now.
  • Binary file reader/writer does the node writing/reading in twofolds. First
    comes the class data, then the instance data. On the reading side, Nodes are
    first instantiated using a simple constructor (either empty or takes Show as a
    param), and then readInstance() is invoked to populate instance data.
  • GrinExtensionWriter and GrinExtensionReader classes are now gone.
  • Adding shared String pool and int[] pool writing in the GrinBinaryWriter.
  • Adding more code to the compile-time generated ShowCommands class, which is
    now called GrinXHelper. For instantiating custom extension classes (user
    defined Features, Modifiers and Commands), GrinXHelper will include an
    auto-generated switch statement that takes care of the class instantiation.
  • Updating MenuXlet to do command selection based on the Director type.
  • Adding a "-debug" flag to the binary writer. It only controls whether name
    section to be written out or not so far.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-38] support scale_model feature
item.description:
Add a support for image scaling that can work upon Box, Image and ImageSequence
by default. It can be similar to a TranslationModel, maybe ScaleModel, and it
can control the horizontal and vertical scale factors, and the
centerpoint of the scale operation that it works upon.

comments.comment: OK
• Issue 13 has been marked as a duplicate of this issue. ***

Part 1 fix (see webrev1.zip):
CHANGE 1:

Re-factoring of "TranslatorModel" and "Timer" into a single
class called "InterpolatedModel". An InterpolatedModel
is a feature that varies a set of parameters over time, doing
linear interpolation between keyframes. This is exactly what
TranslatorModel was. Timer is just a degenerate case of
InterpolatedModel - it has two keyframes (begin and end),
and zero parameters that are interpolated.

Doing this re-factoring sets us up for a third use of
InterpolatedModel, addressing issue 38, "support scale_model
feature". The thing that represents the scaling can be an
InterpolatedModel with three parameters: scaling factor,
and x,y coordinate of center. Note that x,y might not vary
over time; InterpolatedModel handles the case of a non-varying
parameter efficiently.

CHANGE 2:

Fixed some bugs with GrinView. Now it uses insets properly,
and a race condition was fixed when an initial segment is
specified on the command line.

Created an attachment (id=7)
Webrev: Creation of InterpolatedModel

Created an attachment (id=9)
Second part of fix: Creation of scaling_model

Issue closed with putback r196:

Added scaling_model feature. A scaling_model can be applied to
any number of fixed_image, image_sequence and/or box features,
and scale them horizontally and/or vertically, centered around a
given point.

In the bookmenu xlet, this is demonstrated with the segment
S:StartBonusVideo, which has the feature F:UserInput.Success
active. This takes the user input keyboard, rotates it 360 degrees
around a vertical axis, then expands and fades it. Looks great on
a PS/3!

This sample unintentionally shows another characteristic of BD-J
because this somewhat aggressive animation is attempted while a
new playlist is being selected. On many players, the player is
so busy doing the playlist selecdtion that the animation gets
skipped entirely. In a real title, you'd want to do the
animation first, and only then select the playlist, but for this
academic exercise it's worthwhile to leave it as it is.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-37] Support custom feature and allow user-defined binary format for it
item.description:
Currently GRIN includes a partial support for a user defined feature, partly
because the hdcookbook menu xlet doesn't use this. Meanwhile Javelin confirmed
that having this support will be helpful.

Likewise, the binary file converter doesn't support user defined feature.
Instead of trying to define a default format for a custom feature, it's been
agreed that we should add a hook to the converter so that the custom feature can
provide it's own reader/writer routine.

We'll probably update the user defined modifier and command to be able to
provide it's own reader/writer routine as well.
item.summary: Support custom feature and allow user-defined binary format for it

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
The commit for this is currently under review. As a heads-up, possible changes
include:

1. Three new interfaces are defined,
ExtensionsParser, for parsing text-based GRIN file,
ExtensionsWriter, for writing out extensions in binary format,
ExtensionsReader, for reading in extensions in binary.

Those who are using custom extensions should implement these classes.

grin/jdktools/library/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/io/text/ExtensionsParser.java
grin/jdktools/library/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/io/binary/ExtensionsWriter.java
grin/library/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/io/binary/ExtensionsReader.java

2. An abstract factory class, ExtensionsBuilderFactory, is also defined, and it
returns an instance of ExtensionsParser and ExtensionsWriter. This should also
be implemented by those who're using custom extensions.

3. grin/jdktools/library/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/io/ShowBuilder.java have
methods to set/get ExtensionsBuilderFactory instance and ExtensionsReader
instance. GrinViewer, MosaicBuilder, or other SE-based show building tools set
the ExtensionsBuilderFactory or ExtensionsReader instances to the ShowBuilder
after getting class name from a command line etc and instantiating it using
reflection.

Later on, ShowParser checks with the ShowBuilder instance for the
ExtensionsParser in it's constructor. Those who are constructing
GrinBinaryWriter or GrinBinaryReader checks with the ShowBuilder to pass the
right handler in the binary reader/writer constructors.

4. GrinViewer takes -extensions_factory and -extensions_reader command line
parameters, to get the handler impl from the user.

5. For MenuXlet, a new directory
grin/xlets/tools/src/com/hdcookbook/bookmenu/menu is created. All SE based
handler impl, including impl of three interfaces (note, ExtensionsReader here is
for grinviewer only and returns fake versions of Modifier/Command) and
ExtensionsBuilderFactory lives here.

6. The original class for handling extension, ExtensionsBuilder, is deleted.
The getter method at Director.java is also deleted. This causes updates to

grin/jdktools/library/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/MosaicHint.java, is added to save
the mosaic info. I don't like having this class public but can't think of a
better way now. grin/jdktools/mosaic/ classes are updated to work with the new
extensions handlers as well as mosaic hints from SEShow.

8. Changed Show.java to allow null director at it's constructor.

9. Updated SEShowVisitor related methods. SEShow.acceptFeature now calls a new
method SESShowVisitor.visitUserDefinedFeature(feature). The impl of this method

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-36] Reset Features
item.description:
Currently, if a feature that has duration associated with it
(e.g. timer, image sequence, fade, etc.) exist in multiple
segments that are played concurrently, the state of that feature
is not reset when crossing from one segment to the next. This is
critical to a lot of different use cases. However, there are times
when we actually do want to reset the state of a feature even though
it happens to exist in multiple segments that are played concurrently.
Again, the current solution is to have to create a bunch of extra
segments or unique features in order to force the reset, but a
simple "reset <feature>" command could be much simpler.
item.summary: Reset Features

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
r330:

Issue 90: Multiple image map files. Now, the asset finder lets
you specify a list of image map files, which it merges together
into one map.

Issue 10: Auto-return assemblies. Now, visual_rc_handler has
a flag called start_selected. It defaults false for backwards
compatibilty. If set true, then when the handler is activated
it checks the state of the assembly. If the assembly is in one
of the activated states, it is coerced into the corresponding
selected state.

Issue 35: Pre-commands. A segment now takes a list of commands
called "on_entry", which are run when the segment is activated.
This is useful for things like setting the state of a remote
control handler to some initial state.

Issue 36: Reset features. There's a new reset_feature command
that resets a feature to the state it's set to when newly
activated.

<no bug ID>: In image_sequence, the "repeat" flag was being

an end_command causes the show to move to a different segment,

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-35] Pre-commands
item.description:
It would be very helpful to
define a pre-command structure in segments that allows you to
execute a set of commands when entering a segment, in addition
to the commands that get run upon exiting. Right now, we are
having to create a lot of extra segments that server no other
purpose but to run a bunch of commands and go to another segment
in order to get this behavior. That, or we end up replicating
a bunch of commands in each of the different source segments
that feed to a particular segment.

Example: I have a menu prompt that pops up on the screen.
Every time it appears, the buttons on the menu need to be in
a particular state. However, multiple segments may jump to
this one in order to show the prompt. Ideally, we would just
have a pre-command in this segment that sets the appropriate
state prior to the menu being displayed. Currently, we have
to define two segments, one that just auto-advances to its
"next" commands, which set the state and then jump to the
second segment, which displays the menu.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-34] Composite feature
item.description:
It would be nice to have support for a "composite feature" that allows you to "tile" a child feature, and then
use this to build up a full composite feature that acts as a unit.
item.summary: Composite feature

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
This ends up being at odds with the way the animation framework optimizes drawing. You'd need a
parent node that can call it's children multiple time for drawing to make this work. I think that the
most useful application would be to tile an image (and not arbitrary drawing); if so, that's probably best
accomplished by just having a bunch of fixed_image features at different positions that refer to the
same image.

In the more general case, tiling a group of features could be accomplished by cloning the child nodes
multiple times. This can be purely on the authoring side, and could probably be done by programming
in FX/Script eventually. I'm not really sure it's a compelling enough feature to want to build into a
visual design tool, though...

I'm bumping it down to P4, and changing resolution to "later" - it might be worthwhile to reconsider
this when we know more about FX/S at design time, and the visual tool.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-33] Mosaic tool is useful outside of GRIN
item.description: It would be nice to make the mosaic tool work without a GRIN show; it's proven useful for non-GRIN stuff.
item.summary: Mosaic tool is useful outside of GRIN

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Related to issue 70

As part of this, the minWidth, maxWidth and numWidths parameters of Mosaic.java should be tunable
from the show file.

As part of this RFE, apparently part 3-2, G.6 "Number of pixels of an image that can be decoded" sets a
maximum for image size. Error-checking around this should be added to the mosaic generator.

Addresses issue 33, "Mosaic tool is useful outside of GRIN". Now,
there's a mosaics file you can use to specify image mosaics, and
tune all of the parameters. One of the parameters is a set of images
to include in a mosaic regardless of whether or not those images are
used in a show.

This enhanced mosaic syntax also lets the author control the
matrix generation parameters: minimum and maximum width, number
of different widths to try, and the like.

Finally, the GRIN show compiler now accepts multiple show files and
matrix files on the same command line. When multiple shows are
compiled together, they share the same database of images, and thus
they share the same set of mosaics.

Reviewed by Chihiro.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-32] Image sequence with different image sizes, anchor points
item.description:
In some cases, it's important for an ImageSequence to handle different image sizes. Making this really
useful requires an anchor point (center, left, top, etc.)
item.summary: Image sequence with different image sizes, anchor points

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Should just be standard center/right/left both horizontally and vertically; I'm sure I can swipe some
constants from AWT somewhere.
This goes with image effects probably

An efficient way to do this at runtime would be to add a Rectangle[] to the ManagedImage[]. Each
rectangle could flip (or even stretch) the image, and could also re-position it as a way of implementing
anchor points. This won't use much memory, especially if we canonicalize the Rectangle instances (and -
why not - the Rectangle[] itself).

Fixed with r222. Putback message:

Enhancement for issue 32: Now, any image can have a diferent
anchor point and scaline factor. This allows you to save image
memory by flipping an image rather than loading a seperate flipped
version. All scaling/flipping is done at runtime; authors should be
aware that a scale factor other than 1 or -1 might be slow on many players.

An image's anchor point can be top, middle or bottom vertically,
and left, middle or right horizontally.

This new feature is shown with the "spinning yin yang" effect. It
now uses eight images instead of sixteen, because the last eight images
can be obtained by flipping the first eight. The syntax in the text
file looks like this:

feature image_sequence F:SpinningYinYangCCW {
( left 250 top 850 scale -1000 -1000 mills )
( left 250 top 850 scale -1000 -1000 mills )
( middle 313 top 850 scale -1000 -1000 mills )
( right 375 top 850 scale -1000 -1000 mills )
( left 250 middle 913 scale -1000 -1000 mills )

Each image in an image_sequence (or in a fixed_image) can have its
anchor point specified (top-left, middle-right, or any of nine
combinations), and can have a horizontal and a vertical scale
specified. It's specified in mills (that is, thousandths) for
consistency with scaling_model.

Other changes:

Moved animation framework documentation to its own subdirectory,
to emphasize that the animation framework can be used by itself.

Made the "main" target so it doesn't build the sample xlets,
and fixed the building of sample xlets.

Fixed an assertion failure with VisualRCHandlerHelper. As a side
effect, removed the attempted (but undocumented and non-working)
feature of making the cell at <0,0> be the default state. Instead,
the states are now added in the intuitive left-to-right then top-to-bottom
order; the first real state encountered will be the default. Note that
this default is overridden anyway by the UI state in the common case of
a visual RC handler tied to an assembly.

Eliminated a few "import xxx.*" statements.

Changed xlet so that bonus video only starts after the bonus animation
finishes.

Reviewed by Chihiro

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-30] Better optimization of overlapping animation targets
item.description:
In the current animation framework, when two targets overlap they're simply combined into one
bounding rect. This could be non-optimal. Consider, for example, a skinny horizontal rectangle that
intersects with a skinny vertical rectangle.

It might be worthwhile to change the drawing target algorithm to something like:

split damage areas into non-overlapping rectangles
Combine rectangles into an optimal set according to some heuristic

We'd definitely want to pre-allocate the Rectangle objects used for the computation, but they're small
and I'm pretty sure there wouldn't be too many of them. The bigger issue would be time complexity,
which is currently cubic on number of rectangles; perhaps a better heuristic would be needed if we tried
to create this more optimal drawing solution. At first glance, it seems like an area where a pretty
simple heuristic would yield excellent results.

Another interesting 2D computation geometry problem!
item.summary: Better optimization of overlapping animation targets

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: Changing from bug to enhancement

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-29] Automatic creation of set_target features
item.description:
It should be possible to do a static analysis of a show graph and arrive at an optimal set of targets and
set_target features. This would obviously be done at compile time.

Perhaps the rule could be "if the author hasn't' specified a set_target, then the compiler is free to generate
its own, unless instructed otherwise." The "unless instructed otherwise" is needed in the case where the
xlet layers another AnimationClient over or under the GRIN show.

This is a pretty interesting problem in 2D computational geometry, I think!
item.summary: Automatic creation of set_target features

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-28] Pluggable ImageBufferManager
item.description:
It would be nice if the animation framework (com.hdcookbook.grin.animation) had a simple interface that
could be used to acquire and manage the image buffers. This framework could then be used both by the
animation framework itself, and by GRIN. This would allow xlet writers to plug in a more sophisticated
manager that optimizes and manages pixel memory at runtime.
item.summary: Pluggable ImageBufferManager

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
The only place where GRIN uses a buffered image is in the animation framework, in DirectDrawEngine and
RepaintDrawEngine. Making a full-blown framework for managing image buffers seems overkill for GRIN.
Instead, it's easy to make DirectDrawEngine and RepaintDrawEngine just have a protected method the call
to get (and release) the image buffer and the graphics object they use to draw to it. Users who want to
manage image buffers could then just subclass and override these two methods.

I think that the image buffer used by the animation framework is big and long-lived, so in practice I don't
really expect that many people will want that buffer to be a "cut out" part of a bigger buffered image
managed by the xlet.
change status and priority

A putback a few months ago made the animation framework indirect through AssetManager, which solves
this issue. That change was done so that xlets could use DVBBufferedImage in line with the
recommendations at http://wiki.java.net/bin/view/Mobileandembedded/BDJImageMemoryManagement ,
but it had the side effect of resolving this issue, too.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-27] Animation framework documentation; docs refactoring
item.description:
Right now, the "front page" of documentation is a long, windy description of a slightly out-of-date

that the full design exposition is just to get an idea, and not to get an up-to-date idea of the full
feature set.

The BNF of the show file, however, should stay on the front page; that is kept up to date.

More importantly, good documentation on the new animation framework and display optimization
needs
to be written. It should:

o start with the bounding rect algorithm, and say that only changed stuff gets
redrawn with direct draw

o Introduce the drawing targets, by first showing what happens with the "test" show
when things change in opposite corners of the screen, and then show what happens when
drawing targets are introduced.

o Finally, discuss the minor optimization afforded by the "guarantee_fill" feature

To do a good job of this probably requires a pretty visual document with a fair number of screen
grabs, and text that walks the reader through GrinView's "watch drawing" option.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-26] Re-factor GRIN show graph to align with Scenario
item.description:
Eventually, GRIN will be playing with design tools that are targeting the "Scenario" scene graph that is
being incorporated into FX/Script (https://scenario.dev.java.net). There are some unnecessary differences
in naming between the two APIs, so it's worth it to align the naming.

During this refactoring, it makes sense to stop using the runtime show graph definitions for compile-time
tools, like the binary file format generator. As we move more work to compile time, it will help the system
scale if we put these show graph definitions in an independent package, so we don't have to worry about
org.bluray dependencies in stuff used at compile time, and so we don't have to worry about code bloat in
the runtime classes.
item.summary: Re-factor GRIN show graph to align with Scenario

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
OK, so I took a good, hard look at Scenario, which is the scene graph being used for FX/Script. It's at
https://scenario.dev.java.net.

There were some superficial alignments, but I didn't see any big gains to be had from just aligning the
naming. The biggest difference is that the animation framework isn't the same – in Blu-ray,
animation based on being locked at 24fps (or some other fixed framework) is a big part of the idiom,
whereas a desktop machine with a screen refresh of 80 fps is a different animal. Scenario is heavily
based on Java 2D, and uses things like floats pretty liberally.

It seem that the interoperability with FX/Script will come more from the visual design tool side; it
seems to be just a fact of life that the GRIN show graph will be what we use and enhance going
forward, rather than trying to align on scenario's scene graph.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-19] Identify public internal implementation methods
item.description:
There are a fair number of internal implementation methods that are public in GRIN because the
implementation needs to cross package boundaries. This is the classic problem with Java that's solved
with "friend" in C++ (and, BTW, seems like it will be addressed in a better way in JDK 1.7). With the
current Java language, there are various ways to preserve encapsulation, but they're all work and
generally add runtime overhead.

In the spirit of Hungarian notation, we're thinking of naming all such public-but-not-intended-for-
the-public methods with the common prefix "impl." So, for example, the feature Box has a method
called getPlacement() that's really only there for code that needs to write out instances of Box (e.g. the
binary file writer, and the upcoming compiler-to-bytecodes). We'd change that method to
implGetPlacement(). As another example, Show.pushCurrentSegment() is really only supposed to be
called from the activate_segment command. It'd become Show.implPushCurrentSegment().

Standard comments about Hungarian-like notation apply: it's ugly, but it makes it so that an xlet
that breaks the visibility rules is forced to do so visibly, in the xlet code.

If we do this, we've also talked about making a javadoc tag for this, so the implXXX() methods would
be stripped out of javadocs, reducing clutter.

Before we do this, feedback would be most welcome!

Some of the issues have been fixed, and some we've pretty much decided not to address in GRIN...

Issue 61, "Programmatic control of show events"

(no issue #) Harmless race condition

Fixed a race condition with remote control input events. This
race condition would be incredibly unlikely to occur in practice,
especially where there's only one GRIN show being animated, because
the remote control input thread would have to pre-empt the animation
thread between the time addDisplayAreas() completes and when paintFrame()
starts, which is a very short time. Even if that did happen, the way
the drawing optimization works would have prevented any incorrect
display from lasting more than a frame. With
all this said, now mouse and remote control input is deferred until it's
unquestionably safe to process it.
