comments.comment: Triggering a command when two Sprite features run into eachother
Assigning to myself.
The part about "motion control commands" has been split out as issue 61.

Discussed with Bill and Jaya that one simple approach is to compute the bounding
rectangle of a moving object from frame 1 to frame 2, and see that if these
bounding rectangles intersect, for each objects that wants to listen to the
collision. The animation framework (AF) is the one that knows where the object
has been and will be placed next, so the collision nodes will have some
registration system with the AF, and for each frame advancement (even if the
animation is behind and AF won't paint the frame), the AF needs to do a check on
the collision nodes.

One question that came out is, what is the real life use case of this collision
feature, since it can be overly complicated for doing a generalized case.

This doesn't really belong as part of GRIN. It's more appropriate for a game engine that has some kind of
model of the physics behind the objects that potentially collide.

===============
Introducing a binary format for GRIN show. The writer at
grin/jdktools/binaryconverter/src/ directory reads in a text-based GRIN script
and writes it out in a binary format to a filesystem. The reader at
grin/library/src/com/hdcookbook/grin/io/binary reads in this binary format file.

MenuXlet's Director is changed to read in a binary file instead of menu.txt.
The build process for the MenuXlet uses the binary writer and generates a binary
file "menu.grin" from menu.txt, and bundles that file in 00004.jar instead.

For the current syntax of the binary file, see the class comment of
GrinBinaryWriter.java or GrinBinaryReader.java. It's made of series of data
block based on DataOutputStream and DataInputStream, and it is subject to change.

Summary of changes are:

  • Introducing com.hdcookbook.grin.io.binary for the binary file support.
  • The classes at com.hdcookbook.grin.parser now moved to

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-4] Box edges overlap when drawn
item.description:
The class com.hdcookbook.grin.features.Box creates the appearance of rounded
corners and wide edges by using a combination of fillArc() and fillRect()
commands to draw the outline. However, the coordinates are defined such that
each of the edge rectangles extends 1 pixel too far, causing it to overlap with
the arcs in the corners. This becomes visible when using a thick outline (e.g.
outline=10) and a partially transparent color (e.g. color=rgba(128, 128, 128,
128)).

The original drawing code for the edges:

gr.fillRect(x1, y1 + t, t, h - t2); // left
gr.fillRect(x1 + t, y2 - t + 1, w - t2, t); // bottom
gr.fillRect(x2 - t + 1, y1 + t, t, h - t2); // right
gr.fillRect(x1 + t, y1, w - t2, t); // top

should be changed to:

gr.fillRect(x1, y1 + t, t, h - t2 - 1); // left
gr.fillRect(x1 + t, y2 - t + 1, w - t2 - 1, t); // bottom
gr.fillRect(x2 - t + 1, y1 + t, t, h - t2 - 1); // right
gr.fillRect(x1 + t, y1, w - t2 - 1, t); // top
item.summary: Box edges overlap when drawn

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-3] Box.addDisplayArea() truncates area
item.description:
The class com.hdcookbook.grin.features.Box implements the addDisplayArea()
method incorrectly. If the Box is not the only feature in the current segment,
the area it defines is truncated on the right and bottom by one pixel:

area.add(placement.x + placement.width - 1,
placement.y + placement.height - 1);

This can result in the Box having the right and bottom edge clipped when later
drawn.

Correct implementation should be:

area.add(placement.x + placement.width,
placement.y + placement.height);
item.summary: Box.addDisplayArea() truncates area

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Accepting the CR. Additional information about the problem from the submitter,
including the grin script snappit, is below.

---- Start information ----

What I observed was that a box that defined the right-most or bottom-most
edge of the content in the current scene would have 1 pixel truncated
from it's right-most or bottom-most edge, respectively. For example,
the attached image shows the problem using the following boxes:

feature box F:Box1
( 300 200 600 400 )
outline 1

{ 255 0 0 128 }
;

feature box F:Box2
( 300 500 599 799 )
outline 1 { 255 0 0 128 }

;

feature box F:Box3
( 700 200 900 400 )
outline 1

{ 0 255 255 128 }
;

feature box F:Box4
( 700 500 899 799 )
outline 1 { 0 255 255 128 }

;

In this example, Box2 and Box4 define the bottom edge of all the features
rendered in the scene. Both have 1 pixel clipped off the bottom edge.
Box3 defines the right-most edge, and it has 1-pixel clipped from it's
right edge. (Box4 stops 1-pixel before Box3, so it doesn't loose
anything.)

---- End information ----
Fix commited for r67, change to Box.java as suggested in the bug report.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-2] grin_viewer gets confused when it falls behind
item.description:
The animation loop in grin_viewer has a logic bug - when it gets behind, it gets confused and starts
animating too fast. This bug is not present in the cookbook menu xlet.

To work around the bug, always set a frame rate that's low enough so it doesn't get behind.
item.summary: grin_viewer gets confused when it falls behind

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: The animation loop for GrinView was replaced by the animation framework, so this issue is resolved.

item.title: [HDCOOKBOOK-1] ShowParser fails if no ExtensionsParser exists
item.description:
The documentation indicates that using an ExtensionsParser is optional.
However, if one does not have an ExtensionsParser, a Null Pointer Exception
will occur while parsing animation scripts. The problem appears to be in
ShowParser.finishBuilding(), which calls extParser.finishBuilding(show) without
first checking if extParser is non-null.
item.summary: ShowParser fails if no ExtensionsParser exists
